175990673,"Avoidance - Avoidance is the practice of withdrawing from relationships with other people as a defensive measure to reduce the risk of rejection, accountability, criticism or exposure. Nope, this implies AvPD, which doesn't fit. Belittling, Condescending and Patronizing - Belittling, condescending & patronizing speech is a passive-aggressive approach to giving someone a verbal put-down while maintaining a facade of reasonableness or friendliness. Nope, if I put people down I intend for them to know I'm not being friendly, but most likely mocking. Chronic Broken Promises - Repeatedly making and then breaking commitments and promises is a common trait among people who suffer from personality disorders. Sure, but its not like I can help it, at the time I mean it unless lying, but then I can't be bothered to follow through. Circular Conversations - Circular Conversations are arguments which go on almost endlessly, repeating the same patterns with no real resolution. With myself maybe, but not other peo
ple from what I know. Cognitive Dissonance - Cognitive Dissonance is a psychological term for the discomfort that most people feel when they encounter information which contradicts their existing set of beliefs or values. People who suffer from personality disorders often experience cognitive dissonance when they are confronted with evidence that their actions have hurt others or have contradicted their stated morals. Nope. Confirmation Bias - Confirmation _PERSON_ is the tendency to pay more attention to things which reinforce your beliefs than to things which contradict them. Nope, not as implied anyway, it just gets boring reading so much that you disagree with, so why bother so much or equally to things you agree with or find interesting...I can read garbage if interesting, but boring...goodbye. ""Control-Me"" Syndrome - ""Control-Me"" Syndrome describes a tendency that some people have to foster relationships with people who have a controlling narcissistic, antisocial or ""acting-out"" nature. Erm, no. D
enial - Denial is the practice of believing or imagining that some painful or traumatic circumstance, event or memory does not exist or did not happen. No, but memory is deceptive for me and I was always fantasy inclined, so some images I don't know if really happened, but no denial involved. Dependency - Dependency is an inappropriate and chronic reliance by an adult individual on another individual for their health, subsistence, decision making or personal and emotional well-being. If I can get someone to pay my way e.g. rent, food, etc, by all means, but not relying on others to make decisions for me or for emotion well-being. Depression - When you feel sadder than you think you should, for longer than you think you should - but still can't seem to break out of it - that's depression. People who suffer from personality disorders are often also diagnosed with depression resulting from mistreatment at the hands of others, low self-worth and the results of their own poor choices. No. Dissociation- Dissociatio
n is a psychological term used to describe a mental departure from reality. Most certainly, but this is a complicated thing and the term is pretty varied, but I don't use it as trauma or stress avoidance, rather as daydreaming or it can just happen. Entitlement - Entitlement or a 'Sense of Entitlement' is an unrealistic, unmerited or inappropriate expectation of favorable living conditions and favorable treatment at the hands of others. No, I'll take whatever I can get and maybe make demands, but I don't see self as entitled to anything, but take a chance at easily getting things/what you want by presenting entitlement, but I don't actually feel entitled. Escape To Fantasy - Escape to Fantasy is sometimes practiced by people who present a facade to friends, partners and family members. Their true identity and feelings are commonly expressed privately in an alternate fantasy world. Fantasy inclined sure, but I use it for more reasons than said here, and not sure I present a facade (unless intentionally to get 
something), I just don't reveal self as much. Feelings of Emptiness - Some personality disordered individuals experience a chronic and acute sense of nothingness or emptiness, so that their own existence has little worth or significance outside of the context of strong physical sensations and relationships with others. Feelings of emptiness sure, but the description is way off and if anything I fill self up with love of art and escaping to fantasy, not that I see either as intending to fill emptiness, which is just a recurring thought that pops in now and them, rather than constant state. Hoarding - Hoarding is the practice of accumulating items to an extent that it becomes detrimental to quality of lifestyle, comfort, security or hygiene. Kind of, but no guarantee I will eternally hold onto things, I've horded things for years and then just got rid of when no longer saw any use or purpose e.g. my old men's magazines I used as masturbatory aids as a kid, pretty sure I kept them in bags till 25 when I just dec
ided upon seeing to throw away. Identity Disturbance - Identity disturbance is a psychological term used to describe a distorted or inconsistent self-view. Hmmmm, nah. Imposed Isolation - Isolation from friends, family and supportive communities is common among victims of abuse. Isolation is sometimes caused by an abusive person who does not want their victim to have close relationships with others who may challenge their behavior. Often, isolation is self-imposed by abuse victims, who out of a sense of shame or guilt, fear the judgment of others. So this is what I make other people do? I force isolation on them not me? If the former nope. Invalidation - Invalidation is the creation or promotion of an environment which encourages an individual to believe that their thoughts, beliefs, values or physical presence are inferior, flawed, problematic or worthless. Sounds like too much work and effort when you could just ignore a person, or just mock them straight up and be done with it. Lack of Conscience - Individ
uals who suffer from personality disorders are often preoccupied with their own agendas, sometimes to the exclusion of the needs and concerns of others. This is sometimes interpreted by others as a lack of moral conscience. I prefer deficient conscience, rather than a lack...and I see nothing wrong with being preoccupied with own agenda, I'm the most important person to me. Low Self-Esteem - Low Self-Esteem is the common term used to describe a group of negatively-distorted self-views which are inconsistent with reality. Nope. Masking - Masking describes the practice of covering up one's own natural outward appearance, mannerisms and speech in dramatic and inconsistent ways depending on the situation. hmmmm sort of, but also not really, I have to really care to do this but point is I can and will if need be. Neglect - Neglect is a passive form of abuse in which the physical or emotional needs of a dependent are disregarded or ignored by the person responsible for them. Sure, but can't always help this without 
harming myself in some way and I come first. ""Not My Fault"" Syndrome - ""Not My Fault"" Syndrome is the practice of avoiding personal responsibility for one's own words and actions. lol you got me, but this is kinda random, and if caught out with evidence, I won't continue to skirt responsibility but won't care about being caught out. Objectification - Objectification is the practice of treating a person or a group of people like an object. Sure, but not anyone I would say I genuinely have any care for. Pathological Lying - Pathological lying is persistent deception to serve one's own interests with little or no regard to the needs and concerns of others. A pathological liar is a person who habitually lies to serve their own needs. Dislike term ""pathological"" but sure, but while I do lie to serve own interests, I also lie for seemingly no reason, other than maybe to maintain a distance and not risk developing some connection or revealing aspects of self. Projection - Projection is the act of attributing o
ne's own feelings or traits onto another person and imagining or believing that the other person has those same feelings or traits. Nope. Selective Memory and Selective Amnesia - Selective Memory and Selective Amnesia is the use of memory, or a lack of memory, which is selective to the point of reinforcing a bias, belief or desired outcome. No, I don't think so. Selective Competence - Selective Competence is the practice of demonstrating different levels of intelligence, resourcefulness, strength or competence depending on the situation or environment. lol yes, helps get out of things. Stunted Emotional Growth - Stunted Emotional Growth is a difficulty, reluctance or inability to learn from mistakes, work on self-improvement or develop more effective coping strategies. Kinda true, but I relate this more to avolition and lack of motivation. Tunnel Vision - Tunnel Vision is the habit or tendency to only see or focus on a single priority while neglecting or ignoring other important priorities. Nope."

175990706,"There are two situations, in my view. There's the anxiety, which you're solving by taking the medicine. And that's great. That's terrific. Let us know how that's working. The 2nd part of the problem, it was with me, can be that perhaps we are unconsciously negative when it comes to solving problems by being told as children that we couldn't solve problems and/or were worthless. Or by our parents solving all of our problems for us and we never had any practice. Then we grow up and are smarter, but our unconscious may be still set on negative from childhood misinformation. So, the column on solving problems said that's best done by thinking positive going into a problem that we can solve it. By thinking positive before we go into a problem (I say, ""Think positive, think positive, think positive') we activate our unconscious to solve the problem. If the unconscious is set on negative, we can't see it so we don't know, it will follow our orders and trip us up. You don't have to change your personality
, just think positive for 5 or 10 seconds before going into the average problem. Then we can go back to being ourselves. Or, one problem at a time, and be positive about that problem. If this works for you, you might want to talk to your niece about that. Just as I'm trying to hand it down to you. Each one, teach one.Post Edited (_NAME_) : 12/2/2020 11:56:38 AM (GMT-7)"

175990708,Haldol and Hyacinths: A Bipolar Life by _NAME_
175990709,"One can feel old, or one can feel vital, but society has a difficult time defining what it means to age well. Since the largest share of healthcare expenditures goes to treating people over age 65, it’s easy to view old age from a medical perspective. But this does a great disservice to the elderly and their sense of self-worth. The medical model views old age in terms of physical health. Important factors that are considered when defining successful aging include the absence of disease and good mental and physical functioning. But one does not have to be disease free to define themselves as successful. In terms of physical health, 50% of all seniors believe they are aging successfully. By the medical model, only one-fifth are. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/08/what-does-it-mean-to-age-successfully/"

Occasionally when it is really bad I will take a decongestant pill and that helps a lot...only if the greater volume is caused by some congestion. My ""normal sound"" seems to have changed a bit recently and now resembles birds chirping...at times, and that is a bit more pleasing than the sound of a jet engine ramping up. 174389502,"It has occurred to me that at this present moment in time and as the title would suggest, being the best description of what I am experiencing right now. I have even compared this experience to other more tangible things like revenge for hire, molka, cyber hazing, frapping, and workplace mobbing. As the
y all share the very simple characteristic aspect of torturing a singled out victim for the consumption of the baying mob. 175990764,"I agree with JOMP. In certain situations, intuitiveness will only get you so far. It's like trying to see the back of your own head: you can use a hand mirror, but even then, the image won't be spot on because it's filtered by the angle of the mirror and limited by its size. The conditioning he mentioned is probably different for everyone and varies by degree, but I don't see how anyone can get a clear assessment of their behavior or how others see them purely by subjective exploration. Most of us are unconsciously protective of our emotions. We don't want to get hurt or taken advantage of, so we engage in our own personal, private confirmation bias."

175990804,"My mother, a professional psychotherapist for 40 years, who dealt with many addiction patients and gender role/identity clients would likely reply to you something along the lines of: 'Oh you can most definitely overcome alcoholism without question.' I think she'd acknowledge that it's going to be tough, but your battle will ultimately succeed or fail depending on your own will to really stop, period. She would place this responsibility squarely on your shoulders and tell you that it's up to you. There is no in between. No halfway. No sort of trying. That you either really, truly want to and make the necessary changes accordingly or you don't and are choosing not to face a reality that you never honestly really wanted to quit to begin with in the first place. I truly believe that's what she would say, and there likely is truth to this notion. As for feeling sexy in women's clothes, I think she'd say something like ' Who says your urge to feel sexy is not normal? This in and of itself is not a disor
der. To the contrary, it's the norm. So who says what determines and how one feels sexy is normal? Society, right? Why, because you happen to be a man? Most everyone wants to feel more attractive in some way. Right? That is normal. So allowing society to dictate how you feel sexy in the privacy of your own home is perhaps not as abnormal or unhealthy as simply not being honest with someone you supposedly love and having so much shame about it. People have all kinds of proclivities that don't fit neatly into how society might appear to demand one to conform in some way or another. Maybe this was not ultimately why you lost this woman. Maybe it was just reactionary shock on her part because you weren't honest from the beginning throughout. And the alcoholism likely kept you at arm's length anyway. Maybe she's not done with you, but rather feeling hurt and betrayed. Maybe you should try and talk it out honestly with her about what it is you think about some light private cosplay makes up for what you feel has be
en lacking in your self-security of feeling sexy and discuss why you're compelled to hide it. Fear of non-acceptance likely being the prime motivation. And if she can't get over it, then maybe she really wasn't the love of your life that you thought she was.' End of session. I think my mother would say the alcoholism is by far and away your bigger issue and probably contributed to your fear of being upfront and honest about it with her and yourself by allowing fear and shame to overshadow the entirety of your whole self of you really are and what role both alcohol and the light private cosplay play in fulfilling certain weaknesses in your own self-perception. Now you don't know my mother, but I guarantee you she is pretty damn smart. Her son certainly is. Detox, quit drinking, and start being honest by accepting yourself and not deceiving one's you claim to love. Love is not love otherwise."

175990807,"I too have bipolar disorder and can relate to how your feeling right now. This outbreak and it’s consequences, keeping us inside and isolated, is sooo hard. I’m right there with you about being jealous of people who can just get a routine down and do it. It feels like it should be so simple but it just isn’t for people like us. Hell, I can’t even keep a routine of brushing my teeth in the morning each day (gross but...it’s true). My mind wanders and I change plans, do what I want to do whether that’s doing a dumb task that will not help me in my quest to clean up my house, or staying in bed most of the day. Most of my friends are 3 hours ahead of me timezone wise so it’s hard to connect and I end up feeling very alone. I can feel my depression getting worse because one of my coping tools for it is getting out and/or being social. And we have to do this for another month?! That feels like an eternity and it’s worrying to me for my mental health. The one thing I’m doing that helps i
s just living by the mantra “one day at a time”, going by how I feel that day and not ignoring my thoughts/feelings but addressing them and doing the best I can. It might not be the recipe for a good routine every day like it seems like everyone else can do, but we’re not like everyone else - and that’s not a bad thing. Stay strong, we’ll be stronger for surviving this. Xo"

175990855,"The comments reminded me! 1. Yes, it can actually be pretty boring lol. Lots of watching t.v. or reading. There were day activities and visits with doctors, case workers, etc. but mostly boring (especially on the weekends). 2. I was generally quiet and out of the way or stayed in my room (and it annoyed me when the nurses tried to get me to talk or smile lol...I was SO not in the mood most of the time). There could be some minor disruption if other patients were having a hard time or got violent. However, there was always some on staff to take care of that (admittedly I was on of those people...tried to break a door down with a chair. Yeah...I was having a rough time that stay.) But honestly, mostly boring. 3. There were a couple of times when I didn't want to be discharged. I wasn't ready to have to deal with the world again. I got care and support in the hospital. I could get away from the world for a little bit and that was incredibly healing. So, all to say that for me hospital stays really wer
en't that bad in and of themselves. I got the care I needed. I'm grateful that they were there in crisis."

175990865,"Hi maddixone, I hope it works well for you! Everyone is different. It didn’t work for me. I’m on Zoloft and buspar now with good results. As for the inhaler, albuterol is known for elevating your heart rate. I’ve been on it much longer than I’ve had anxiety issues and it’s always been a problem for me. It doesn’t cause me to panic but it does cause high heart rate, weakness, and chest discomfort. Might want to talk to your doc about other options."

175990949,"ritalin, adderall, psuedoephedrine. haven't had anything stronger than that. i'd never realized how much my head was this vortex of constant humming white noise of disorganized information until i tried stimulants and everything just... clicked into immediate organization and went quiet. i was surprised how smart i was. for example, ask me question right now and it'll sound vaguely familiar but i won't know the answer. ask me the question on meds and the answer falls from my mouth in an instant. the difference between my capabilities medicated and unmedicated is staggering and stark. but alas, i'm unmedicated. not even sure i want to be regularly medicated. i'm unsure how important processing power is to me regularly. not very, i suppose. though i should make a habit of grabbing some stimulants when it comes time to research or whatever i need to do."

175991057,"Hi _PERSON_! I also have social anxiety and I've been working through it for the past year or so. So when I had to take public speaking for college, I was terrified! That anxiety is by far one of the worst feelings ever! For when I did my speeches, I always tried to limit the amount of anxiety I had during the day. One step I can advise is to prepare well for the speech before the deadline. I'm not sure what your teacher's guidelines are for a public speech, but I would follow them closely for the speech. Above all, practice, practice, and practice some more even if it feels silly. I know I sound like a teacher, but when I did prepare and I knew that my speech was going to be great, I felt less anxious about embarrassing myself. Asides from that, my last advice is towards your classmates. Believe me, EVERYONE is going to be anxious for the first speech. And I'm sure people are still going to be nervous throughout the semester. So know that you're not alone in that class. Secondly, even if you feel 
that you embarrassed yourself, most people won't even notice or judge you. Most of the time, people are paying too much attention to how they are viewed in front of their peers. And everyone is going to be too occupied with their own anxiety to notice your's as well! Lastly, even if you feel that you embarrassed yourself, and you feel that everyone noticed, don't worry too much. People are very understanding and they won't judge you negatively. I'm sure your peers have all felt embarrassed or anxious at times. And because of that, they'll sympathize with you and they'll be understanding. I wish you the best for your speech, and you will get through the day on Tuesday! If I can survive through 5 public speeches with social anxiety, then I'm sure you can get through it too. All the best to you friend!"

175991069,"Seems like you're going through a lot - Although you tend to be able to distract yourself well so it's likelier that your mood symptoms could be 100% because of the decrease in Thorazine - Which is unlikely I think - Idk if a decrease in medication can cause suicidal thoughts alone.. In the way where me for example.. was suicidal after drinking alcohol - Really badly. There was underlying causes as to why I was feeling that way. I drank alcohol again - BECAUSE I was suicidal. Then I processed the feelings and they went away. Idk if this helps as insight or is useless. Take care of yourself. Throwing up isn't good for bulimia recovery - Can be triggering. It reminds me of how I am addicted sometimes to drugs and yet take medications - You have to think yourself out of it and use logic, feelings... We're not always going to be perfect and the choices we make that we think are good will lead to bad results just like the bad choices we make can lead to good results - Less often than the former though b
ut it still counts. I usually get inspiration from you cuz idk what I'm quite confused but I noticed that you seem to be doing well, then stop meds and do bad. It's a cycle but eventually you can catch yourself with realization of habit like how people quit doing something when they're ready - In an opposite way. We're changing constantly. Need to dance with the chaos and move with it. Many jinxes happen and me saying I jinxed you un-jinxes it. It's ok cuz we're all supportive and wants what's best for each other.."

175991081,"Speaking of mistakes and worrying over them, here's a mistake I made about 3 days ago. I was talking to three people in my kitchen and making a grand presentation, I thought. It's the most people I've had in my kitchen in 6 months and I was later thinking how wonderful that experience was. After that, I looked in the mirror and it looked like I hadn't blown my nose in a week, or that I had blown my nose 5 minutes before these people arrived, and hadn't wiped it off. My idea of my great presentation and wonderful social experience was taken off the board. Then I was left with, how do I think about that? Well, at first I was totally devastated. Then I thought, how am I going to balance this out so that it's not so bad? I thought, look at the positives, wonderful social experience, good ideas exchanged, compared with, totally embarrassed. But two or three of the things were good, I told myself. I also thought, learn from that. Next time, look in the mirror before the company comes. Also, there are no 
guarantees here. Not every situation has to be wonderful. As in grow up. Life is not always as we want it. So all that's left is learn to deal with what we get. And learn from the mistake, don't dwell on how I'm going to turn back the clock and wipe my nose before they arrive. That's childish. Look at the positives you've done in the last few days and weeks. Your mind might be set on the negatives because you might be a negative thinker. You are looking for that. Reset your mind to positive. Say, think positive, think positive, think positive when you come across an upcoming problem to solve, which in your case this time is getting over a blunder. Believe going into it that you can get over this. Think of people who are worse off than you and how you can help them. All the time we spend thinking about our nose or our latest blunder, could have been spent trying to help someone who is worse off than we are."
175991082,thanks you guys…I am really happy with it.

175991095,"I have been taking 100 mg of Zoloft, 75 mg at lunch time and the remaining 25 mg at night. Same 100 mg per day, though. It has been about a week since I started that. I have noticed that, since I made that change, my anxiety has been worse. Some days really bad. I am wondering whether it could be because of this change. Or maybe it is just a coincidence, since I certainly had bad anxiety days when I was on the 75/25 mg regimen too. I guess I could go back to the 75/25, but I don't want to do that yet -- too much moving and moving back is not great. Of course, I could ask my pdoc, but he is away on vacation. 175991125,"I had a surgery on my left breast in 2000. I had microcalcification. Well when I felt pain in my left breast years later I was worried. I had gotten fibromyalgia at this time. Come to find out the pain in the breast area was in the pectoral muscle. From costochrondritis that you can get along with the fibro. I still get chest and shoulder pain and it has been almost 20 years since I got the fibro. I also get muscle spasms in my chest. I can't stretch anymore because my muscles always spasm. It has only been 7 months since your last mammogram so you probably can't get one yet unless doctor feels it necessary. How old are you? I used to get pain in my breasts when I was younger due to hormones and what time of the month it was. I feel if you are concerned you should call the doc or nurse. You are prone to health anxiety so you are going to worry more. A lot of times people with breast cancer don't feel pain in the beginning, but they will have a lump or a strange texture to the skin (like orange peel
). Generally it is on the outside of the breast. And often lumps can be cysts or calcium deposits. Try not to worry about it or dwell on it. But get ahold of someone if you are extremely worried about it. It is better to know for sure than to worry about it. I hope that your day gets better. Hugs, _NAME_..."

175991157,"I suppose you could make that link. The body snatcher has a whiff of collective takes over. My analogy was not appropriate in that sense, its more fundamental and can happen in any relationship. Also people are replaced by plants with no emotions, which is part of the scary, but that would not apply either. I just liked that movie. That city of Socrates is the second one, and not the ideal just city. The ideal just city is where everybody minds their own business and do their own things. They live a self-sufficient life, but obviously also a poor one. His definition of justice, which is the goal of the play, is ""to mind your own business"", and the ideal city's citizens do just that. However, after he describes said city, people listening to him take offense and tell him this is a city of pigs, with no luxury or anything worth living. The second city, which is the main part of the book, is best case scenario, what would happen of a city that wants luxuries. So he starts with a city where everybody 
is the same, has the same origin, so the same culture, and everybody is smart and wise, but even then the wisest gets to rule. And then he follows the downfall of that city point by point. So the moral of the story is that you can't fake your way into justice. If you deny the first principle, no matter what you do, it will corrupt over time, no matter how hard you try to make it otherwise perfect. It's true for justice, but also for any first principles. People always think they can get away with just this little bit of exception which breaks the rule. So the whole play is a slippery slope argument. Hadn't make the connection with orcs and nationalism. For sure we take our identities from our culture and traditions, without knowing it. At least for the most part. I agree with that, and it is well.. quite traditional. Well, it's German. I remember reading stories about it, and I am not sure which one it was. I tried to find the origin of it. https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/h ... ppelganger What I was thi
nking was probably from _NAME_ Christian _PERSON_, or the changeling tales. It's the idea that someone is being replaced by a double, with different personality. I thought about it, especially in the case of the changelings, and I wonder if it is not a case of fear of letting children out of your sight. Lots of tales about that. Goblins may steal them, but they can be replaced by changelings and you won't even notice, so better not take any chance. If the _PERSON_ had taken those tales seriously, maybe the goblins would have been thwarted. As it were, they simply took the little _PERSON_, and goblins are good at hiding under the Earth, so you never can find that child again. That's assuming you absolutely have to take something from others, and that the only protection is friends and family, which you can't protect yourself from. So in the end, it makes no difference if that is the case, but I don't believe it is. People can pick and choose what they believe in, and pretty much always do, but customs give a r
eservoir of stories for everybody, but not every story is for everybody. Although I can see what you mean, and there is some truth to that. People that deny family, customs and religion have only really one source of information, and that would be the State approved ones, from the institutions. Often stories are used as subversion of current narrative. The body snatcher story was probably such a story. However, I did not bring out those myths in that sense, and I denied it twice already. I brought it up as a more existential threat, and the threat is not in the real of ideas, values or morality, it is more of a bodily threat. Or an loss of agency threat. Because if you kind of become one with someone, it is hard to tell who's agency you are following. Your own, or the other's? So you'd better know what you stand for before hand, or potentially be manipulated and cease to exist. Which reminds me again of the _PERSON_. Its clear to me from one interview, that the mother is completely fused with the husband. She 
has lost her agency to him, or he took it, but essentially, he talks for her all the time, and she does not push back at all. She also talks weirdly, in an impersonal matter, as if she has trouble taking agency and responsibility for things. She is in some sort of dream where things happen and she is not all there. Not sure if it is a dependent personality, or a case of abusive husband or something, but the relationship looks toxic. So its that type of fear, or becoming like her."

175991200,"It's good that you are seeing your doctor this week. Having a doctor is not a guarantee. We are very fortunate that we live in a time that we have doctors and good medicine. I've already told you the story about my mother's mother, who had bipolar in the 1920s, 30s and 40s, and there was no medicine during that time. They had to be treated at a central state mental hospital. And they had no medicine. We're being treated in our homes, not 100 miles from home with no medicine to help. As I said, she would go into people's medicine cabinets and take some of the pills, hoping one would help her. None of them did. But she could hope. We live in an era when there are many tablets that can help. We are very fortunate. You say, ""I have another appointment this week. May even ask about another antidepressant. There are so many options out there."" You know how your current antidepressant is working, so you would know how that's going. I was going to ask if you were still depressed, if your antidepressant w
as working, but you said your mood was OK, so I figured maybe that medicine was working. So I'm glad you brought up that subject. You said, ""From reading about bipolar many are not properly diagnosed until 10 plus years after symptoms. That is scary."" I've even seen it on webmd.com under the bipolar topic, one of the psychiatrists was getting onto the others, saying ""If your patients come in as depressed, determine if they are manic depressed before diagnosing them as depressed."" I mean, really? Misdiagnosed means miss-medicated. Means possible panic attacks, like I had when given only an antidepressant. And then when I would see him next appointment, he would say, ""Well, what have you been doing this week that would cause a panic attack?"" And you say, ""Also each episode causes brain damage?"" That could be a possibility. Let me tell you what a panic attack feels like. They started when I took my first antidepressant with no stabilizer. They would come 30 minutes after I had taken my antidepressant (wi
th no stabilizer to put a hold on the antidepressant). Right as I drifted off to sleep, I would wake up out of my mind. I would sit straight up in bed, And I wouldn't know where I was. I would think, there's no pill you can take for this. There's no tranquilizer, for I'm already out of my mind. Sometimes I would go to the ER. This went on for, several months or more? I would tell my psy., and he would say, ""Well, what have you been doing that would cause you to have anxiety attacks?"""

My dad answered and stood my mom was at home, she was sleeping after a dental procedure and he would go check on her and my brother after work. This wasn't good enough for me... little detail is that I am in California and they are in New Mexico. I called my brother back and he told me you don't have to worry about mom and I will take care of dad... to save on horrifying details, my brother murdered my mom. I have been going to counseling for almost 2 years now due to this. 175991268,"Hi. I'm in a pickle. I'll explain slowly and see what you all think. I had been on lexapro for years at 20mg. When I fell pregnant it wasn't effective, my anxiety hit the roof and it was hell. As I wanted another baby one day, when I felt okish I decided to wean of the escitalopram and take venlafaxine as my sister has just had a baby on it successfully. After 9 days of being on venlafaxine I just couldn't cope anymore. The first couple of days I felt really sick and had hot sweats, then I had intense headaches and migraines, when I looked at my computer screen it was like all the font was protruding out and I'd look at the wall and I can still see the font, sounds wierd I know. Then by day 4/5 came the crippling anxiety. When I was younger I was severly sexually assaulted and while that was happening, he kept on telling me I was 'crap' and 'my life was crap' over and over. It got stuck in my head for ages like it was on repeat. Think it was all connected to the stress of what had happened, but whe
n ever I get anxiety, these thoughts come back, which heightens my anxiety even more. After 9 days on venlafaxine, my doctor switched me back to lexapro at 20mg, no tapering, took it for three days and felt like a rattle snake for the next doctor to tell me to take 10mg, I took that for 8 days felt no better at all and for the last 3 days I've taken 15mg. My doctors have prescribed me with zopiclone to sleep took it for 4 days, didn't work. They've now given me 5mg of diazepam once a day, previously had 2mg twice a day. They've given me 50mg of trazodone to help me sleep. I still feel awful. I was in AnE last week as I didn't feel I could cope with any of it anymore. Every one keeps telling me it will get better. But it doesnt. My heart beats so hard in my chest I feel like I'm vibrating. My arms feel like they are on fire. I'm terrified I'm stuck like this."

175991277,"Back in 2016, I could count on one hand the kinds of interventions that technology companies were willing to use to rid their platforms of misinformation, hate speech, and harassment. Over the years, crude mechanisms like blocking content and banning accounts have morphed into a more complex set of tools, including quarantining topics, removing posts from search, barring recommendations, and down-ranking posts in priority. And yet, even with more options at their disposal, misinformation remains a serious problem. There was a great deal of coverage about misinformation on Election Day—my colleague _NAME_ found, for example, that when Twitter tried to deal with content using the hashtag #BidenCrimeFamily, with tactics including “de-indexing” by blocking search results, users including _NAME_ adapted by using variants of the same tag. But we still don’t know much about how Twitter decided to do those things in the first place, or how it weighs and learns from the ways users react to moderatio
n. What actions did these companies take? How do their moderation teams work? What is the process for making decisions? As social media companies suspended accounts and labeled and deleted posts, many researchers, civil society organizations, and journalists scrambled to understand their decisions. The lack of transparency about those decisions and processes means that—for many—the election results end up with an asterisk this year, just as they did in 2016. What actions did these companies take? How do their moderation teams work? What is the process for making decisions? Over the last few years, platform companies put together large task forces dedicated to removing election misinformation and labeling early declarations of victory. _NAME_, a professor at UCLA, has written about the invisible labor of platform content moderators as a shadow industry, a labyrinth of contractors and complex rules which the public knows little about. Why don’t we know more? In the post-election fog, social media has beco
me the terrain for a low-grade war on our cognitive security, with misinformation campaigns and conspiracy theories proliferating. When the broadcast news business served the role of information gatekeeper, it was saddled with public interest obligations such as sharing timely, local, and relevant information. Social media companies have inherited a similar position in society, but they have not taken on those same responsibilities. This situation has loaded the cannons for claims of bias and censorship in how they moderated election-related content. Bearing the costs In October, I joined a panel of experts on misinformation, conspiracy, and infodemics for the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. I was flanked by _NAME_, an ex-CIA analyst; _NAME_, a disinformation fellow at the _NAME_ Center; and _NAME_, head of analysis at Graphika. As I prepared my testimony, Facebook was struggling to cope with QAnon, a militarized social movement being monitored by their dangerous-organizations department and 
condemned by the House in a bipartisan bill. My team has been investigating QAnon for years. This conspiracy theory has become a favored topic among misinformation researchers because of all the ways it has remained extensible, adaptable, and resilient in the face of platform companies' efforts to quarantine and remove it. QAnon has also become an issue for Congress, because it’s no longer about people participating in a strange online game: it has touched down like a tornado in the lives of politicians, who are now the targets of harassment campaigns that cross over from the fever dreams of conspiracists to violence. Moreover, it’s happened quickly and in new ways. Conspiracy theories usually take years to spread through society, with the promotion of key political, media, and religious figures. Social media has sped this process through ever-growing forms of content delivery. QAnon followers don’t just comment on breaking news; they bend it to their bidding. Sign up for The Outcome - A newsletter on U
S election integrity and technology. Enter your email, get the newsletter Sign up Stay updated on MIT Technology Review initiatives and events? Yes No I focused my testimony on the many unnamed harms caused by the inability of social media companies to prevent misinformation from saturating their services. Journalists, public health and medical professionals, civil society leaders, and city administrators, like law enforcement and election officials, are bearing the cost of misinformation-at-scale and the burden of addressing its effects. Many people tiptoe around political issues when chatting with friends and family, but as misinformation about protests began to mobilize white vigilantes and medical misinformation led people to downplay the pandemic, different professional sectors took on important new roles as advocates for truth. Take public health and medical professionals, who have had to develop resources for mitigating medical misinformation about covid-19. Doctors are attempting to become online infl
uencers in order to correct bogus advice and false claims of miracle cures—taking time away from delivering care or developing treatments. Many newsrooms, meanwhile, adapted to the normalization of misinformation on social media by developing a “misinformation beat”—debunking conspiracy theories or fake news claims that might affect their readers. But those resources would be much better spent on sustaining journalism rather than essentially acting as third-party content moderators. Related Story Thank you for posting: Smoking’s lessons for regulating social media Former Facebook executives admit they used the tobacco industry’s playbook for addictive products. Perhaps it can also be used to undo the damage. Civil society organizations, too, have been forced to spend resources on monitoring misinformation and protecting their base from targeted campaigns. Racialized disinformation is a seasoned tactic of domestic and foreign influence operations: campaigns either impersonate communities of color o
r use racism to boost polarization on wedge issues. _NAME_ testified about these issues at a congressional hearing in June, highlighting how tech companies hide behind calls to protect free speech at all costs without doing enough to protect Black communities targeted daily on social media with medical misinformation, hate speech, incitement, and harassment. Election officials, law enforcement personnel, and first responders are at a serious disadvantage attempting to do their jobs while rumors and conspiracy theories spread online. Right now, law enforcement is preparing for violence at polling places. A pathway to improve When misinformation spreads from the digital to the physical world, it can redirect public resources and threaten people’s safety. This is why social media companies must take the issue as seriously as they take their desire to profit. But they need a pathway to improve. Section 230 of the Communications and Decency Act empowers social media companies to improve content moderation, but p
oliticians have threatened to remove these protections so they can continue with their own propaganda campaigns. All throughout the October hearing, the specter loomed of a new agency that could independently audit civil rights violations, examine issues of data privacy, and assess the market externalities of this industry on other sectors. As I argued during the hearing, the enormous reach of social media across the globe means it is important that regulation not begin with dismantling Section 230 until a new policy is in place. Until then, we need more transparency. Misinformation is not solely about the facts; it’s about who gets to say what the facts are. Fair content moderation decisions are key to public accountability. Rather than hold on to technostalgia for a time when it wasn’t this bad, sometimes it is worth asking what it would take to uninvent social media, so that we can chart a course for the web we want—a web that promotes democracy, knowledge, care, and equity. Otherwise, every unexplai
ned decision by tech companies about access to information potentially becomes fodder for conspiracists and, even worse, the foundation for overreaching governmental policy."

175991287,"_PERSON_ said... If you're feeling happy, you're probably thinking that the present as well as your future looks good. If you're feeling dreadful, very nervous, and panicky, then maybe you're thinking that not only is the present bad, but your future looks bad too (not to say that your future actually looks bad). Maybe that's why you feel suicidal only when you're feeling dread and panicky, _PERSON_. It's just my theory. Exactly. So basically I can be happy and feel fine 364 days of the year and not have any of those thoughts, but the minute I have that anxiety attack the feeling of dread and those weird thoughts come. To me it’s just your mind not wanting to be in the situation at that time leading to weird intrusive thoughts. Then I’m happy and fine for several months without those thoughts and the little anxiety that comes from time to time is easy to manage. Then a bad one hits and in that moment those weird feelings come. The hardest part IMO is feeling guilty about it for the next week or 
so and obsessing why I thought like that in that moment. That’s why I added the post that I don’t think of ways to do it, I just feel like I could be stuck in that moment of panic forever and that dread sets in."

175991293,"I have ringing in the ears or tinnitus. I got it from firing the rifle on the rifle range with no ear protection. Do you know how yours started? Does your tinnitus also lead to being sensitive to noise and hearing loss? Mine has. What can help me, with the being able to hear a little better for a little while, is putting an ice gel pack on one ear for about 30 or 40 seconds, and then the other ear. It reduces the inflammation as does such cold on the lower back, etc., during back pain. Also helping to calm the ears is an extended length heating pad, which rushes oxygen and nutrients to the injured area, such as the lower back and the ears. My technique for this is, to moisten the pad's cloth insert, or a small kitchen, etc., towel, wring out the excess water, put the heating pad on high on top of a pillow, put the moist towel on top of the pad, lay my right ear on the pad and wrap the other end of the pad around the back of my head and over my top ear. Again, with an extended length heating pad, bo
th ears are getting the benefit of the moist heat. It is psychologically and physically soothing. I lay like that from 5 or 10 minutes to 30 minutes. Sometimes I even go to sleep and may wake up an hour later. I can also do this when I lay down to sleep. Sometimes when my ears are bothering me, I tell myself, if your ears are really bothering you, why don't you get up and put the heating pad on your ears? Sometimes I don't want to do that, but it gives me a reason to quit worrying about it so much if I don't feel like getting up and putting the heating pad on my ears. I would also not go around a certain level of noise, for, in my case, lead to sensitive ears to noise. I would not go to rock concerts, or listen to music over a certain level, or ride in airplanes. I would not use a lawn mower or chain saw, or other loud equipment. High pitched warning bells on ovens and cars, car alarms, backup beepers, are all beyond me. If you already have tinnitus, I would not keep testing my ears around those.Post Edited (
_NAME_) : 12/28/2020 11:48:43 AM (GMT-7)"

Birdbirdbird, does it support you in your topic, when I share my own confusion about it ? The moment 
when I realized that a sufficient amount of lying means good social behavior and lack of lying is bad social behavior (too much maybe as well), was when I read a book from an experienced professor about personality disorders. When he explained ""manipulation"" he pointed out that humans are constantly manimupating, constantly sending ""pictures"" to other people. The jacket you wear, the bike or car or whatever (skateboard ? you ride, the way you walk and talk. Everything is subconsciously filled with manipulations to put images into the heads of people around you (incl. yourself). So manipulating IS social behavior. And lying is just one color in the huge palette of manipulation. Maybe religions that claim lying to be a sin, if you live in a region that was shaped by such a religion, gave our society a wrong understanding of lying. Lying is good, it saves people from harm. That doesn't mean that petreyal is good. But lying alone doesn't make petreyal bad, it's the petreyal that makes it bad, right ? (Know wh
at I mean ?). Hope you can resonate with some of my thoughts."

174390263,"You go, newtus. I totally support you in this. I believe psychology has created some tools and schools that have been helpful to many, but, I alsoe believe its reliance on this ridculous, 1600s-era concept of ""the mind"" and ""the psyche"" has dramatically slowed progress for patients with these illnesses. I know it is an unpopular belief I have, but until we all recognize that bipolar disorder and schizophrenia are diseases of the human brain and that the human brain is an actual organ of the human body with specific electorchemical and endocrine functions and processes that can be slowly understood through real, sicientific research, we will continue practicing like _NAME_ in an SNL sketch about medieval doctors using gnomes and toads to cure us all."

175991414,"I agree chat is useful for immediate responses. On a board such as this one, you might get three or four responses within, say, 24-48 hours. On the chat, that might happen in 1 minute. Of course, quality of response matters too. Here, the responses tend to be on topic, compassionate and often informative. That is not always the case on chat boards. They sometimes get off topic or worse. But I like the chat I participate in because it is fast and very international. Earlier today I was chatting with people from the UK, Europe, Australia, and the Middle East at the same time, while I am located in the United States. We were talking about OCD and related anxiety and the treatments that we have undergone. So I guess both are good just in different ways. There is also an app that I use which has a number of different message boards, add a private message function. I have found that useful toO. One problem with some boards is that they do not have any active participation. There are a few mental health r
elated boards that have basically dried up with only a few people participating; they quickly become useless."

Though I would still like to advocate for mental health, if only I can find a way that people would actually pay attention to. A few years ago I came across a disability group that was looking for stories, so I gave them mine, which was basically ignored. Then just recently I found they're doing a TV show, kind of a cute Freak Show, with wheelchairs. I had forgotten one basic principle: Image isn't everything, it's the Only Thing. We've all heard that appearances can be deceiving, it is also written that: _NAME_ But the LORD said unto _NAME_, Look not on his countenance, or on the height of his stature; because I have refused him: for the LORD seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the LORD looketh on the heart. I have been advocating for people with mental illness for over thirty years now, and I have a name 
tag from a show I did for Creative Sanity over twenty years ago saying, ""Mental Health Matters."" More recently in Ohio a friend at church and I tried starting a community program for disadvantaged people that came to a bad end and fell by the wayside, which is another long story. I had also been active online, but any ""Connections"" I may have made on the internet also seem to have fallen by the wayside for one reason or another. With the pandemic and more people going online I had hoped that this would be an opportunity for me to continue my advocacy work. I have seen a few groups online promoting mental health care and fighting _USER_ID_, but they get nowhere near the coverage that the more popular issues get. Every day I see people begging for poor furry four legged critters that are abused and abandoned and need our help, where there are many human beings who are abandoned and need help simply because their brains do not work as well as some people's, or in the way that other people think they should, 
and hardly anyone is paying attention. I have come across instances of abuse of people with mental illness by the police, some have even died in custody, and the only outcry is from a few aggrieved relatives, and those reports you have to go looking for in order to find. So I am still here, still wondering how to advocate for people with mental illnesses, but I am at a loss as to how to make mental health care seem cute and sexy. If anyone cares to comment, I am open to suggestions. Hopefully I will be notified if people respond to or follow this post, but then I check my email every day so if anyone writes me personally I will respond. Peace, and may God Bless, _EMAIL_.com"

175991430,"jobs i've done that i think fit perfectly night shift security guard: specially in places like schools, malls, remote government locations (power plants etc) truck driving: not bad, but long hours. truck driver are surprisingly social & very friendly contract courier: medical documents/supplies, medical patients, amazon prime etc. i love driving, you can just zone out, listen to music & do your thing, much more stable than Uber/Lyft or Doordash type stuff night shift warehouse handler: i was the only product picker on my floor, lots of time to play on my phone, work at my pace with little to no supervision IT: remote work is the best, but help desk stuff ain't bad data entry: remote from home, always a win artist: if you like doing something artistic there's probably nothing better. set your own hours and work as much or as little as you want in a given day, live frugally of course. or any self employment with demand where you can work how you want pretty much anything night shift or remote/working 
from home"

175991445,"Usually it helps to have your doctor's support in going off of APs. I was able to get off of Zyprexa and am now taking half of the dosage as I was before of Abilify (I was on Zyprexa and Abilify and two ADs at once plus Klonopin at one point). I think it's probably best to see what your doctor has to say... I know in the past for myself whenever I thought of going off of my meds it was kind of a red flag that something else was going on. Like the desire to go off of meds itself isn't bad, it's just acting on it that's bad (at least in my own case). I get really impulsive and that becomes problematic."

175991459,"I don't know how long to make this and I don't want to seem arrogant. I have Depersonalization disorder (DPD) but I marked it as depression for the sake of grouping. I'm a young man of 21. You may skip ""my growing up"" if you don't want to read everything. My growing up/trauma I lived in a sheltered christian environment my whole life. I went to private schools from 1st to 12th. My parents were not abusive or anything like that. I may have been teased when I was a kid, about my weight, but nothing that brings back distressing memories. The only seriously bad thing that came to me from the environment was that my parents got divorced around 10 years ago. I was around 12 or so I think. I lived with my mom from then on and visited my dad a few couple times a year. At the time, I didn't rlly care that my parents were divorced. I was kind of glad actually. My parents were quite restrictive on how much tv/computer time I was allowed to have, something to like 30 minutes a day. Since they got divorced an
d whenever I visited my dad, I was able to play as long as I wanted on the computer, 24/6. I remember in the divorce counseling room this lady asked me and my brother, perhaps my sister too, to draw a picture of what the divorce made us feel. I _NAME_ a picture of a bird pooping on my brothers head, for humors sake. I didn't care that I wouldn't see my dad in the same house anymore or that they were fighting. Perhaps I was too engrossed in my videogames. Growing up from that time, I went from being a super shy kid who player games alot, to an athletic guy who was good at sports and was respected for this by others, for example: (similar to another person) I cried at the slightest things, for example, I found a leaf outside of the school grounds which was red, (I being like 12 or so) I tasted it and it was spicy, it was a precious leaf from then on. Later that day I had my leaf on my desk and another kid came up and teasingly, not meaning any harm by it, crumbled my leaf. I started crying uncontrollably. They 
didn't understand at first why I cried so. I wasn't normal in this regard. I would cry in the middle of class at least once a year for one reason or another (giving a book report). I was very absorbed in sports from 5th grade to 10th grade. I was aiming for the best and I had the right to, for I was among the better players in my private middle school and high school. I was drunk on adrenaline it seemed (I played football and soccer mainly). It was my life. That was taken away at the end of 10th grade. Everyone seemed to be a ball hog. They wouldn't pass me the ball or give me the chance to prove myself, even when I likely had a good deal more experience then them. It was humiliating. I gave up soccer and football because of how immature all those players of my grade and around my grade level were. It hurt a lot. I had practiced everyday, more than others. It was my life. The next year or so, another bad thing happened. I fell in lust with this girl at my school. She was pretty, though I didn't talk to her mu
ch, my heart longed for her. Sometime later that year, as I was getting closer to her. She got kicked out of school for giving someone a blowjob. She stopped messaging me after that. I cried in my free time for 2 days. The final two years of highschool for me is similar to the state I am now. Currently I have had depersonalization disorder for around 9 years. I was about 12 I think. It was around the time my family got divorced. It didn't notice it before a few years ago. Seems that suffering some loss caused me to be aware of what I lost. Now tell me if you have something similar. For it would be nice to have someone who can understand my great loss. I don't really feel anything anymore. I don't really feel love, or sadness, or joy coming from the heart. I have no friends or family who I can feel love from or love. My family, my brother, for example. I have nothing against him and we should be close, for we played videogames all the time together growing up. But now, unlike when I was a kid, it makes no diff
erence who it is who is beside me. I don't think I would grieve or care much if he or my family were to die soon. My heart seems to be cold. Like my heart is an emptiness. The only thing coming from it seems to be an occasional pain. Not emotional pain like heartbreak, but if you can imagine it, a emotional, not physical pain that is unlike the common emotions, the pain of nothingness. It is all day everyday without anybreak. I was distracted by sports in middle school and highschool which is why I probably didn't notice it. But it has been like this for a long time. Things haven't been real for a long time. Things haven't been beautiful. I wish everyone understood what I mean when I say real. It's like eating an apple and it having no flavor. What made life worth living has been gone for awhile, but just recently within the past few years, I have noticed it. My body feels like it is just bones without flesh, like I am just made of sticks and my skin and the sensors on them are just for show. I feel like a pu
ppet, or pinocchio who wishes he could be a real boy. This lack of reality effects every second of my life while I'm awake. It is a type of perception it seems. I am uncapable of imagining or understanding of that reality that I have lost. I have faint slivers in my memory which tell me that there used to be something (The way the world felt and touched me) beautiful in this world that made life worth living. Memories of when I was young, the earliest one of which I was 12. I try to estimate with the fragments of these memories what this reality was like that I have and how much I have lost and the sorrow that should accompany it: It is like if you believe in the body and the soul, it is like I have lost my soul. Like I am the walking dead wandering aimlessly. It feels as great of a loss as if my soul, that thing essential for salvation and heavenly bliss is lost to this (an analogy) devoted believer. So great a loss that I would not compare anything I could think of to be more sorrowful. But I don't remember 
this loss and I am almost completely ignorant of what that reality felt like. It is like having amnesia, and you once had a strong lover but you no longer are able to tell who this person is or to know them anymore. But of course miraculously but still very rarely recognize there voice and your heart yearns for what you have lost but then you forget again. I feel like I am living in hell cursed on this earth. I can't remember the last time life was worth living. I am greatly handicapped as of a year ago, in that my heart will not let me do things I used to do to distract myself. I used to exercise a good amount, study religious things intensely, watch my diet carefully, volunteer, learn new things ( I was learning Hebrew and Greek, self teaching). I had to resort to watching anime and playing videogames with all my time because my heart couldn't handle other things (which is hard to explain). Now currently, I am not able to keep myself busy the whole day without my heart acting up, so just to ease the pain/wh
atever it is, I have to sleep it off and takes naps during the day. Life hasn't been worth living for a while now, but now it is a burden to keep myself distracted from this emptiness. I have little hope that things will ever change to how they used to be or that I will ever be at peace. I have already attempted suicide to escape my seemingly hopeless fate. Since I don't rlly feel emotions I can't tell you this with my heart behind it, but it is a great sorrowing thought that I may never love anyone or feel love and that my heart will always be cold. People who don't understand are many it seems. This isn't something mild. It feels like the difference between heaven and hell (not feeling reality). What is normal to other people seems to be some great fantasy that is found in surreal dreams to me. I know this because I remember glimpses of what life used to be like. What is also bad is that I look to be doing fine on the outside. There is no need for people to show me more compassion because I look just fine! 
I couldn't even benefit from compassion it seems though for my heart is cold. It's not like my choices made me this way. I tried my best to be a good christian and I had good guidance to become one. I didn't take any wrong path that would make me this way. It is just the path laid out for me. Anyways... It'd be cool if I could find people who also understand this sorrow and loss."

175991477,"I am so sorry you are going through this, and I pray that you can find peace through all of this. Are you able to distract yourself when the quiet becomes too much for you? Are there things you like to do that you can use as a distraction such as playing with a pet, music, walking, reading, exercise, gardening, cooking, anything that can serve to fill the quiet space until you can be calm again? If not, will you try at least one thing that can help ground you when you start to feel overwhelmed by these feelings? And please don't feel that your parents don't want to know anymore. Your parents love you and would want to know what's going on with you. Don't feel ashamed about expressing your feelings. Be honest and as calm as possible when you tell them. Makes me think of Proverbs 16:23 ""The heart of the wise one gives his mouth insight And adds persuasiveness to his speech."" What's the lesson? Talk about your feelings openly and honestly but also wisely. Don't assume or answer for your parents what 
you think they might say or think or feel. Make it a conversation, not a sermon. Keep it relaxed and informal if need be, and as the text says, you will add ""persuasiveness"" to your speech. I wish you the very best."

A year ago today, I was leaving a secluded park that I like to visit on the outskirts of where I live. ture so lovely and rich with symbolism. I slowly pulled over to the other side of the road so as not to spook the bird. I rolled down my window and murmured with deep tenderness, ""Well, aren't you a beauty!"" I looked up, a little past the beautiful animal and my gaze fell upon a disconcerted unkempt wild-haired gentleman covered in tattoos who may or may not have been camping in nearby bushes. He stared back at me unimpressed and serious. I think he may have assumed I was speaking to him. Realizing there was no coming back from a situation like that, there was no point in clarifying. Instead, I silently rolled up my window, politely broke eye contact and drove away leaving him standing tense and uncertain."

175991520,"I have read in a number of places that Schizoid Personality isn't about not wanting or liking other people. (Sorry for the double negative, I can't work out a better way to put it). See e.g.: (taken from a post by Dr _NAME_) On this board and others, though, posters sometimes seem almost aggressively dismissive of the possibility of meaningful relationships with other people. I don't mean this is a criticism, everyone experiences their own personality differently. I'm looking to understand and normalise my own experience, though, so I wanted to post and ask about that other side of the schism - loneliness. For me, I very seldom, if ever, directly feel the need to have other people around. I can happily go for days without seeing other people, and I feel far more relaxed when I do so. But ... and this is a big ""but"" ... I feel that I need to be connected to other people. I have a small number of relationships that I value strongly, and I feel very unhappy when those people are upset with me. Even 
friendships that didn't work out, but that I feel could have been one of that small number of valuable connections, have a lot of power over my mind. The paradox is that I only worry about friendship and relationships when I am stressed, and the thing that stresses me most is other people. So I'll find myself having an argument with someone that I care about ... the argument is probably about the fact that I don't want to spend time with other people that I don't care about ... and as a result I'll start having depressive ruminations about old friendships that failed. An underlying factor here is that I am very afraid of losing the good relationships that I have, because I know how hard they were to make and maintain, and how difficult it would be for me to establish new ones. All of these relationships come with obligations - and many of those obligations are second-order relationships that I don't want, but have to maintain to keep the important relationships. I get in trouble any time I admit that I find t
he second-order relationships tedious and meaningless. Is any of this familiar to anyone else, or is it just me?"

Well, I take Mirtazapine anti-depressant to take care of the depressed side of my manic-depression, and Lithium for my stabilizer. Because, as a manic-depressive, if you give me only an anti-depressant, with no ""cap"" on it like Lithium stabilizer, the anti-depressant alone will throw me into mania and/or I will have panic attacks. As a bipolar, I think they're are four things here. One is, getting diagnosed correctly, and we seem to be. And that is not always a given. So we passed the first hurdle, we got diagnosed correctly. OK, second is, we got on anti-depressant, I have Mirtazapine and you are taking Trazodone anti-depressant. Third, we are both on a stabilizer, to keep the anti-depressant from throwing us into mania. You are taking 
Depakote as a stabilizer, and I am taking Lithium for that. But there is a fourth issue. Sleep. Neither one of those is a sleeping pill. The difference is, I'm taking a third item for that, a sleep aid, Melatonin from the health food store, and you aren't. Have you been on your two new medicines long enough that it is OK with your doctor to try that? You can also buy that at a grocery store health food section, possibly, at a drug store or over the net."

175991534,"Yes normally I feel obligated to tell the truth even if it might have negative consequences for me. But there have been a few rare times when lying seemed to happen automatically. Like when I was 11 I stole a cool pen that I had been wanting for a long time from a classmate. I kept bringing it to school (no idea why, it was as if I was convinced I did nothing wrong!) to use it and had absolutely no problem claiming again and again to the boy that my father had bought it and he must have lost his. I cannot understand at all how I did this, it was so obvious I had done it! Normally I would have died of shame! And even if no one had known of my crime, I would still have worried myself sick about it. (I think maybe not having that pen somehow meant to me, that as a person i was worth so very little , and to emotionally survive this, something else in me took control of me?) That is the only time I have ever stolen anything in my life. My mother told me a million times to be good (she simply didn't know 
any better about raising children, all she knew is that they had to be good). For me this meant: allways do what others expect of you even if it goes against your own needs, under no circumstance cause trouble or bother anyone with any problems you might have yourself. This message was anchored deep in me, I was a very good girl, never bothering anyone. I knew the rule to be nice to people, but when I heard someone say that you're also supposed to be nice to yourself, I was genuinely surprised. (This was in my late teens I think). The idea of being nice to myself was so alien to me. So yes I definitely also had and still have those ""good kid shackles"" on me I have realised lately that this left me with the following core thought: I don't matter at all in the world, only what others think or need is important. I guess for freeing oneself you should do opposite of this last thought. Like learning to be nice to yourself, appreciating yourself. Learn what you as a person want and need and act on this to show yo
urself that you are important. I'm in the process of learning this myself, it's not easy. Also think about what you went through in your life but you survived, and not just that, you're even having the will to keep moving forward. You are strong and resilient (you wouldnt have survived otherwise) and so brave and courageous to keep on going"

175149397,"I am a high school student about to be in 11th grade. Because of COVID-19, my sophomore year was cut short back in March 2020. Of course, being inside and staying at home impacted my mental health a little bit. However, I wasn't feeling exactly down because I was just so happy I didn't have to wake up early to get up and go to school. Fast forward to now: I swear on everything I think I am suffering from depression. My sleep schedule is VERY off. I hardly eat but if I DO eat, I'll go 7 to almost 10 hours before having my next meal (and I won't even feel hungry in between meals). I have been having either very weird/uncomfortable dreams or straight up nightmares every time I go to sleep. The only feelings i have right now are just sadness and mostly longing. I miss hugging my friends. I wish I could hug people other than the family members living in my home. My dream would be to be able to just go down to the beach and ride roller coasters on the boardwalk like i did last year. Im also feeling a lot 
of regret too. WAY before COVID was a thing, I would LOVE to stay at home on the weekends. I hardly ever made plans and to be honest, I was always too tired to make plans. Along with school, I would work and then focus on my school work after I got back home from my job. So by the end of the week, I would be so beat and wouldn't want to go out because fridays (along with the rest of the weekend) were my only free days where I could just relax. But now, I wish i DID make plans back then when we all had the option to do that and not have to worry about distancing between friends and wearing masks...because as a result of this pandemic, I have no choice BUT to stay inside and not make too many plans with friends. I hate it. I think some of the saddest parts abt quarantine were when I would drop off a gift at my friend's house. I couldnt go near them...I couldn't give them a hug and say ""happy birthday"". It broke my heart. In addition to the symptoms I listed earlier, for a while I would hardly say anything to 
any members of my family. hardly a peep came out of me unless i was spoken to first. I just didn't want to talk. I have obviously acknowledged that I need some sort of help, and because I can't really get the BEST type of help, I'm trying to incorporate some type of order/routine into my life because before I made the schedule I was a mopey, sad mess. I just miss everything. I just wish this will all go away and then I can live life to the fullest. That's what I said I would always do once COVID-19 was somehow managed (cured, vaccine, etc): ""when COVID is over, Im livin my life to the fullest. 175991651,"Hey there, that must be hard for you to deal with every day. I have extreme anxiety as well… makes me physically sick sometimes when I’m at church or with a large group of people. It took me a while to identify, but my anxiety is triggered by lack of sleep, going shopping if I’m alone, high stressed tones when other people talk, when I’m stressed, or if I’ve made a big mistake (and others point it out to me). My anxiety, depending on the day, depending on my stress levels, will skyrocket when these things happen. Not always, though. And it’s a continuous process to determine what causes my anxiety to flare, I also take some time out of my days to do things to relieve it, yet it still gets to be bad. One trick if you have social anxiety, is when things start getting out of hand… plug in to a soothing instrumental. I’d recommend YouTube instrumentals, or on the Calm app. Both are great options, Calm also has guided meditation and nature sounds, as well. Likely, you’re doing somethin
g/exposing your self to something that triggers your anxiety without realizing it. You are not alone – we’re here for you!"

175991683,"When I had anxiety issues, after a while, I got sick and tired of dealing with the anxieties as well. However, I've been a lot calmer and a lot mentally healthier since. Treatment helped me. And it can help you as well, Angels. Good to have you here, Angels!"
175991684,"One of the most difficult challenges to overcome when dealing with a mental illness is the temptation of the excuse. With a psychiatric diagnosis comes an excuse for everything. Any bad behavior, lack of motivation, or failure can be passed off as a symptom or the result of an episode. The excuse is always available. Don’t take it. No one’s asking you to take responsibility for having a mental illness. That’s not your fault. But you have to take responsibility for your actions. Sure, unexpected things happen as a result of a serious mental illness, but most of our behavior is within our control, or at least our influence. And the behavior that most influences our wellness is compliance. If you have a treatment regimen that works, stick with it. If you had one and left it, get back on it. While many of us bemoan the fact that we’ll never be well, treatment success rates for mental illness are very high. The National Institute of Mental Health has shown success rates for treatment of bipolar 
disorder of 80%, for schizophrenia 60%, depression, 70 – 80%, and panic disorder, 70 – 90%. Compare this to treatment success rates for heart disease of only 45 – 50%. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/06/noncompliance-and-the-abdication-of-responsibility/"

175991714,"Hello, guys! I wanted to ask you today what helped you or helps you the most with your depression. Is there one thing that you know works for you and what is it? I’m gonna start by saying, I think the thing that helps me the most is the support of my closest people. I recently asked my husband did he see me getting depressed. Did he see any change in me and he shocked me by saying “no”. He said “I saw you were crying but that’s it, it was not visible change”. This kind of made me think that if I didn’t tell him I felt depressed he would not get it on his own. I’m introverted and stuff but still I thought my struggle was visible. After I told him that I felt sad and depressed and anxiety is just destroying me, he was there for me. So I think admitting to people that you don’t feel good is a very important first step. Your struggle is not necessarily visible even to you closest friends and family. You have to open up to them. So, was there one specific thing that helped with your de
