175991776,"It's been a while, but I'm back. I've had some new events unfold and it's causing me a great amount of grief. I thought this might be the best place to come back ""home"" to. I've had palpitation problems for years (as my thread can attest to.) In the time since I started posting here I have officially been diagnosed with anxiety disorder and depression. I have started seeing a therapist twice a month to help me get past some of those problems. In the mean time, my palpitations continued, so my doctor got me a screening. I had a blood test, a CT scan, and an EKG done. Everything came back fine on that, but the palpitations continued. The seemed to get worse as I started to have runs of them many nights where I would eat supper and a short while later I'd have what would feel like 3-5 in a row and cause me significant stress worrying that this was a bad sign. My doctor, wanting to give me peace of mind, got back with my heart doctor and had me set up on a three day monitor. The cardiologist gave me 
a clean bill of health following the three day monitor and for the last year I've been fine. Even when I had palpitations or flutters or runs of them I'd shake it off because ""cardiologist said I'm fine."" Then came the beta blocker. My regular doctor wanted my blood pressure down from its average of 140/90 and the lisinopril she had me on wasn't doing the trick so she wanted me to try a low dose beta blocker in with it. She even said that it might help ease what PVCs I did have. I had reservations about taking them, but I gave in. This past Monday I cut the pill in half (she gave me that option) and took it and went about my business. Same thing on Tuesday. Though, on Tuesday I started to have a flare up of PVCs. lt was unusual since I hadn't had many in the last year, and it freaked me out enough I decided to stop taking the beta blocker. My doctor is closed Wednesdays, so I wasn't able to speak to her, but on Wednesday afternoon my PVCs flared up to a point that I've never seen before. I was having dozens 
an hour, and in some cases 3-5 per minute and a few runs of them. This went on all afternoon into the night to the point that by 2am I became so frightened and frustrated that I decided to go to the ER. Thankfully, it was almost deserted so they took me right in to check me out. The nurse hooked me up to the monitors and they did an EKG on me. The head doctor came in about 30 minutes later somewhat bewildered saying that while I was having PVCs, nothing on my monitor or EKG was alarming him in anyway, and he was actually surprised I was feeling them. He did feel that on some level the beta blocker did cause a flare up, but he felt the heightened amount was also causing me anxiety which was playing off of each other giving me worse and worse PVCs. He kept monitoring me for another 2 hours and gave me a blood test. He found absolutely nothing wrong with me other than the fact that I was feeling every PVC I experienced. He sent me home, told me not to take any more beta blockers and to follow up with my doctor. 
Even before I got home the number of skips I was feeling had fallen considerably. I was able to sleep comfortably all morning, and even though I felt a good number during the day Thursday I never got anxious about them. Today (Friday) I went for the follow up with my doctor. She looked at the paperwork from the ER and said the ER doctor was right. There was nothing on my EKG that looked suspect in the least other than the PVCs which she already knew I had. She felt that anxiety played a huge role in this. I came home feeling good, only had a handful of PVCs, and then I went outside. I had a run of them. I don't know how many, I just know I felt several flip flops in my chest and it completely undid everything my doctor and the ER doctor told me. I came in and had a breakdown. I started crying out of a sense of frustration and fear. Here I was just a few hours before being told I was fine, and now I'm right back to square one. After that moment, the PVCs have increased ten fold. Occasional flutters, mostly ski
pped beats or a double beat here or there. Even as I write this, I have felt about one or two PVCs every minute. I don't want to go back to the ER, but it being a Friday evening if it gets worse or I don't calm down it maybe my only choice. Any feedback would be much appreciated. 1 2 3"

175991787,"Great question roxy8820! Anxiety and Anticipatory Anxiety are problems for many but there are ways to successfully cope or possibly overcome these challenges. Keep in mind that ridding ourselves of habits and mindsets that may have dominated our lives for years will take time. Don't be discouraged when you have setbacks. The more you work at it, the more your new behavior will become a part of you. Here are some great practical tips that I have found helpful. 1-Recognize and admit the habit. Ask yourself 'Do I really benefit from this? How much better off would I be without it? 2-Replace the negative with positive. i.e., read, study, or exercise. 3-Monitor your progress for a few minutes daily. If you have a relapse determine what led up to it. 4-Enlist the help of others. Tell friends or family what you are doing and ask them to help. 5-Be balanced and realistic. Do not expect immediate success. 6-Pray"

175991817,"I take 12.5 mgs twice daily Started it as I was taking care of my mom in her end of life stage from afar but involved 24/7 in all the decision making about her care, medications and on the phone with her whenever she needed me (always) and I was so anxious, stressed and guilty about not being able to be there in person. 175991820,"Hey hun, iam so sorry. I to suffer from anxiety, panic disorder and depression. I was diagnosed at 17 but been suffering since I was 16. I been on and off Prozac and Zoloft. The medication worked for me. However, Ill be good for awhile without it until a big change occurs in my life, then back to meds again. Its hard for me to deal with change. Also my mother suffers from the same thing. Mental illness unfortunately has a lot to do with genetics. Maybe your parents have been diagnosed with it? It's important to find the root of the problem. What helps me is being outside, keeping a diary, if you have pets, cuddling with them, exercise and painting. _PERSON_ offers some really great anxiety management classes too. Im 32 and still deal with it from time to time but for the most part I have kept it under control as best I can to where I can live comfortably again. For me what is tough is the anxiety part. I need to be alone during those rough times and noone seems to get that. From experience you can 
get better. It takes a whole lot of hard work and dedication but it is definitely possible!!! Don't give up!! Most importantly remember you are not alone!!!"

174390938,"Idk if hyperphantasia is common but I seem to have a form of extreme hyperphantasia. Some people have aphantasia and can't imagine anything at all. I feel like I have a lot of talent that I was way too depressed to ever take advantage of. ""Hyperphantasia Checklist Consider this something of a checklist or guide of sensory completeness and simulation in imagination. I think it might be a good idea to have people ask questions about exactly how detailed and accurate their imaginings are. Visual - Picture an apple on a plate. What color is the apple? What variety is the apple? (Red Delicious, _NAME_, Macintosh...) Which direction is the light coming from? Is there a specular reflection - ie, a shiny spot, as if light is being accurately reflected by the skin of the apple? Are there imperfections in the surface? Roughness, subtle variations in the color of the apple? Is there reflected illumination from the plate onto the apple? Can you easily zoom in on the apple, rotate it, etc? How faithful to an a
ctual 3-D physical object is this in your mind's eye? Audio - Imagine a song, one with vocals and instruments. Pick one you're familiar with. Does it have all the instruments? Are the vocals changing pitch, tone, etc? Are the vocals actual words, or just sort of gibberish fitting the role? (Try singing along to whatever is going through your head out loud if you're not sure) How sharp are the drums? Can you change the tempo? Can you make the singer sound like they huffed helium? Can you swap out instruments? Swap out lyrics wholesale? Can you change the key or mode of the song? Touch/Proprioception - Imagine your hand and an object, any object, in front of you. Can you mentally reach out and touch it? Does the object feel like it should? Hard/soft, hot/cold, smooth/rough, etc... Could you feel your own imagined hand and arm? Were you aware of the physical movements in the same way that you know where your physical arm/hand/fingers are without looking? How heavy is the object you imagined? The right weight? Ca
n you change that weight? Close your eyes (mentally or physically, whatever works) and concentrate on that imagined hand. Start with the thumb. Tap it to your palm. Do the same with your index finger, then your middle, ring, little finger. Any problems? Can you keep going? In other words, can you continue to 'tap fingers' with fingers you don't have - imagine that you had extra fingers - despite not having a real-life analogue to compare to? Can you go a step further, and imagine the feel of wholly alien things (bird wings, say) that will require entirely fictitious input? Smell - Imagine a flower, preferably one with a strong smell Can you smell it at all? Does it smell strong enough, or just a faint whiff? Is the smell accurate - a rose smelling like a rose? Can you make it smell like something else - fresh cookies, say? Multiple smells at once? Rose, cookies, old stinky socks? Taste - Seems to be pretty rare, but... imagine a few foods. Can you taste them? If you imagine something salty - like a pickle or 
potato chips - and add imaginary salt to it, does it taste saltier? Can you distinctly tell apart the taste of distinct items, like, say, two flavors of chips, or two kinds of candy bar, or two different wines? Kind of the acid test: if you imagine a few foods and what they would taste like together, can you go in your kitchen, get those foods, eat them together, and have them taste the same? That is, are your imagined tastes demonstrably the same as the real thing to a degree that it would be useful cooking?"" I also seem to have a mild form of synesthesia. ""Synesthesia is a condition in which one sense (for example, hearing) is simultaneously perceived as if by one or more additional senses such as sight. Another form of synesthesia joins objects such as letters, shapes, numbers or people's names with a sensory perception such as smell, color or flavor."" Like if I look at my water bottle right now, I see the number ""5"", which is female (I can tell whether a number feels male or female to me) and it remi
nds me of science. I look at my wallet and it reminds me of the number ""4"" (Male) or ""8"" (Female) and it reminds me of firewood or a forest with the mix of a CIA agent (Which makes me think of number 1 - neutral or 7 - male) for example even though it's black with someone surfing on it. I could go on and on about the objects I see in my room or even imagine some in my peripheral vision and describe synesthesia related to that as well. Music can be colourful but in general reminds me of colourful machines or metal waves but can be like colourful flowers or a range of objects and images. Interesting stuff that I never realized before. I'm wondering if anyone else with schizophrenia/psychosis has this or is it evidence that I'm more autistic? I can read emotions in faces extremely well so idk. I've never had real visual hallucinations (Only extreme hypnopompic and hypnagogic ones before sleeping or after waking up where I would have conversations with people that weren't there) but I've had visuals on weed a
nd psilocybin that manifested as strong imaginations that I could literally see very clearly as if they were real. I've had many auditory hallucinations though. Some inside my head like hearing a bell in my head but in the form of words, from behind doors calling my name or people talking and whispering near my head or people having conversations beside me when no one is there."

175263870,"Feeling friendless and alone is difficult, and depressing. It is important to know that depression will spiral and feed upon itself. Depression is, like Satan, the father of the lie. The lie that you are not worthy of any love, even self love. Don't listen to the lies. There is so much beauty to enjoy that depression blinds us to. Let me tell you how I beat depression - and my story makes some people angry because they think I am dissing their pain. I am not. I am just saying what helps me. I had excruciating pain from my psoriasis and could/would not take painkillers. I read how smiling produces serotonin and that reduces pain levels. Despairing and desperate, I put on a fake smile. The more I smiled, the easier my pain was to handle. So I started plastering such a big fake annoyingly Pollyannaish grin on my face a few people were creeped out! I couldn't even randomly catch a stranger's eye because they thought my maniacal smile was aimed at them. I got fired from a job because I smiled when a hig
her up was angry at me and thought I was being disrespectful! But not only could I handle my diminished levels of pain, all my depression lifted and I was in a great mood. I discovered the secret of happiness by enduring excruciating pain: Put a smile on it. So PLEASE when you feel down SMILE SMILE SMILE. It really helps me and I get in such a better mood when I deliberately put a big (at first) fake smile on my face. Scientific studies show that the physical act of smiling releases serotonin. So just keep putting a smile on your face. Weirdly, it was my pain that made me keep putting that smile on, because it would remind me to smile. The more I hurt the better I would soon feel. Best to you and do not despair. Smile."

175991964,"Yeah 20 mg is a very big dose of Zyprexa (it's the maximum FDA-approved dose I think, if I remember right). I have been on 20 mg Zyprexa before as well. And yes, it made me very sedated. The key is to find a balance of a dose that works for you yet doesn't cause too much sedation. I am on 5 mg of it now, and it doesn't make me tired, and when I take it at night, it helps me get to sleep. Meaning it doesn't cause sedation in circumstances during which I want to be awake. It only makes me sleepy right before bed, which is ideal anyway."

175992011,"Your words. Nobody else's as far as I'm aware. What makes this outbreak so confusing to so many people such as yourself is that the disease, as far as disease in general goes, is not particularly nasty. It just isn't. As far as diseases that nobody has immunity to, however, it just about makes the cut as nasty enough to be concerning. And that's all it takes for it to be deeply concerning. When the snowy slope is as big as the entire world population, just the fact that there is a snowball is enough. And the fact that the disease in itself is not all that scary is what makes it an order of magnitude more concerning than it would be otherwise (compounded to another order of magnitude by the fact that it seems to spread silently). Because the relative safety that each individual feels is exactly what dramatically increases the chances of a seriously bad outcome for everybody. It's a ""tragedy of the commons"" type of situation. Catching the disease yourself is, in all likelihood, not a big deal. But 
everybody catching it all at once is nothing short of a major catastrophe. Because, out of all the infected people, a few semi-random ones end up needing medical attention, and they need it badly. And ""a few out of all"" multiplied by eight billion is a frickin lot. Way beyond what any society could hope to be prepared to deal with properly. Way beyond the point where the ones at risk of dying from the disease itself aren't the only ones anymore at risk of suffering badly from all the systemic ramifications. Eventually you will, just like eventually happened with past pandemics. That much is inevitable and completely beyond control. The question that remains open is whether or not most people will eventually know someone who died or developed some kind of lifelong health complication from this one. Within the realm of plausibility, the ideal horizon at this point would be if a scalable effective treatmeant were discovered/developed in the next few months (which isn't something that can be counted on, but is 
definitely not impossible either). But barring that, all we can do is delay things. If we don't delay things, then people will still end up hiding inside anyway, for fear for their own / their family's life and wellbeing. But the dark irony is that that sort of spontaneous fear would only kick in after it's not very helpful anymore. Once most people have that personal reason to fear the disease (meaning: they know someone who's suffered from it), then the outbreak is already running its course, or has run it entirely already. Then the economy will be waiting for them to rejoin, and they'll be hiding in fear. The idea that the economy is specifically suffering from the measures being taken, and by nothing else, stems from the idea that only deliberate acts have consequences. But viruses and volcanoes and so on just don't care about that. The economy is suffering from the pandemic regardless. You don't need to trust me or believe me on this. You only need to accept that that's the nature of a pandemc, and that 
pandemics happen. Then you automatically know that, if you're going to question the fact of a current pandemic, then the only reasonable course of action is to do it starting from a place where you assume it's real and act accordingly."

175992027,"I don't feel pain like normal people. I dissociate from it. Y'know ketamine (A dissociative) is a painkiller right? They use it in hospitals for pain for humans and in vets for animals. I have a different persona that pretends that bad things don't happen. It's like sometimes I'm not really there. I agree with people that say bad things about me. I'm easy to manipulate. When I realize what someone has done to me, I still think of it as a funny thing. I don't take things seriously enough. I know a lot of people that are so down on themselves that everything is just black and darkness. They hate their parents, get into bad relationships and smoke cigarettes like they really want to die. When I'm down on myself, I'm just frustrated - But I'm mentally autistic. When I want to die, I think of it like a playful thing. My tragedy isn't after I die and ""He had it hard.. - there was no light, it was a very serious thing"". For me, it's like my tragedy is like a kid scraped his knee and started crying. I do
n't know how to explain it. I didn't die - After all the drugs I took.. There's a connotation to hard drugs like they destroy lives and they deserve it.. That's what people think. I did them out of delirium. Like a manic dream. My life is a mania. When I'm depressed, I use humour. I never lose my sense of humour. There's something called ""Sad clown paradox"" where it seems like most comedians are depressed or have been through depression or just seem to have some inner sadness. I was the most popular in middle school because I was so funny. I like making people laugh because it makes me laugh. Yet such deep philosophical thoughts.. I remember sitting in the playground wishing I wasn't alive when I was 10. I didn't want to play soccer with a tennis ball. Outside school I had a lot of friends. I was an annoying person sometimes and people would call me out. I've been afraid to be myself until psychedelics. Psychedelics made me feel like a kid again - Without the societal meaningless robotic jobs everyone goes 
through, the depressive alcohol drinking and cynical cigarette smokers, the assholes putting people down to make themselves feel better. I always did and will lift people up and the jealous ones put me down. Every time someone does that, it's like a relationship with that person that I have which is an entity that takes his/her form. Something that haunts me to make sure I stay balanced, - Then I continue doing what I do, which is try to live and be myself, change, grow. But at the same time those dark depressions were harder than anything I've ever been through. I did want to die and walked alone through it all. But I don't remember my pain. The feeling was all gone in depression. Everyone left me alone. One kid was like ""Come to the party, drink alcohol"". He really wanted to help. But I was on some journey walking on some dark road, completely lost. The shroom helped. Alcohol wasn't what I needed. It's never what anyone needs."

175992116,"A man from around the corner walked to the end of the block and shot himself Friday night. Someone called the police and said an older man had a gun and was threatening to hurt himself, and boy did the police respond. There were patrol cars and officers everywhere. When they entered the man’s apartment and found he wasn’t there, they fanned out in every direction. They found him in the ivy in a small wooded grove that abuts the highway. They taped off the area, and neighbors gathered across the street to watch and wonder. His daughter arrived, wailing. Back on the block someone brought out drinks and a little summer happy hour began. No one paid much attention to the suicide, other than a passing comment or even a wise crack about what had happened. The man was truly alone. I spoke to the woman who lives next door. I made some sardonic comments and nonsequiturs. I wanted to talk about anything else. Since I attempted suicide myself in 2002 I haven’t been able to deal with the topic around oth
ers and have met it with black humor and withdrawal. But it’s not funny. I went back in the house. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/older-bipolar/2019/08/a-suicide-in-the-neighborhood/"

175992166,"SACshmo: I told you I hadn’t been back to too much of my past in a while because of a woman who had given me some advice at an Al-Anon meeting, which I said I was going to tell you about later. But prior to my telling you about that, you said in a post, ““I hate how emotional I am, but I love how I am in general.” The part of how emotional you are reminded me of some sayings, which I wanted to pass along first, and then I was going to tell you about what the woman said at the Al-Anon meeting, witht _PERSON_ being for spouses or friends of alcoholics. OK here’s what the woman said at the Al-Anon meeting. First, I have felt sorry for myself all of my life. My mother, who was sexually abused and remained at the emotional age she was when that happened, would have been threatened by my growing more emotionally mature than she was. So she would have set out to keep me immature and would have criticized/rewarded me to keep me in line. So, at 43, at this al-anon meeting, the group leader was giv
ing everybody a chance to talk. There weren’t but about 4 or 5 people there. When it came my turn to talk, I started spouting my troubles, feeling sorry for myself. I droned on and on in a pittyfull tone of voice. When I finally got through, the woman next to me, said, “Oh, you were having a Pitty Party. We’ve all done that.” Now, as speeches go, that’s probably not the best one you’ve ever heard. It was going to be for me. Well, she was chastising me in front of the group. She was calling me a big baby. But she did it in a feminine way. She also said, “We’ve all done that.” She was rescuing me and correcting me at the same time. She was like those nurses that give you shots: “This is going to hurt, but it’s going to help you, also.” So it got through my defenses. It got to my psychic. She wasn’t saying it in a hateful manner. She was looking right at me as she said it. She was sitting right next to me. I’m looking back at her, stunned, and in front of the group, but reading the st
ern but understanding look in her eyes, which said, ""Take this shot."" Now, as I’ve said before, I don’t know if she was an angel or what. And as they also say, one person can make a difference. She made a difference. After that, I never felt sorry for myself again. Whenever I tried, I saw that woman’s face, and I heard her voice, and the baby that had been in me was not there. There was no reward for that, only a woman who I respected more than my mother cautioning me. So I grew up that evening. And it has helped immensely. And then you said, “Also I’d like to point out that the therapeutic part of this site is that I am able to know I am not alone, along with being able to talk about my life. Again, thank you all for sharing.” So I felt you didn’t want advice you wanted some stories. But I wanted to add a word of caution for that, so I said, ““Here of late, I haven’t gone that far back into my past, my childhood. It might be because of a woman who gave me some advice at an Al-Anon meeti
ng, which I want to tell you about later, but you said it was therapeutic to know that you are not alone, “along with being able to talk about my life.” So that’s the story of the woman at the Al-Anon meeting."

175992204,"When I started changing my eating habits I started with small things at a time. Like one month I switched to 2% milk, then at some point fat free. Add some more vegetables and fruit over carbs and red meat, eat more fish and poultry, especially turkey. Maybe switch out one junk food item you generally eat during a week for example like a bag of chips for a piece of fruit and some kind of protein like walnuts. I know that's just a brief description but basically don't make sweeping changes at once and don't cut out all treats. It's okay to have some now and then, depriving yourself will generally backfire to overeating junkfood. There's not really bad food and good food most has a place it's just things need to be balanced and done in moderation. It took me a couple years to change my diet to fairly healthy. I used to eat chips and pastries and pizza, etc tons of it every day. Now I just have some once in awhile. It takes time and patience, weight takes time to come off as well."

175992223,"Some things I do to calm down are: Put an ice pack on the back of your head. This will cool down your brain and reduce activity in your limbic system, where emotions happen. Do a task with simple, clear steps. I like baking. I follow the recipe, and it’s easy enough that I don’t get frustrated, but it requires enough concentration that I don’t have room to think about other things. Cleaning also helps. Engage your five senses. This will remind you what is real and what isn’t. Listen to soothing music. Smell something pleasant, like an essential oil. Suck on a hard candy. Look at pictures of things you enjoy. Feel something with an interesting texture, like a piece of Velcro or a stress ball. Try to levitate something with your mind. You obviously won’t succeed, but it gets you to focus all of your attention on a single point outside your body, instead of on your thoughts. I like to use this on airplanes or in public places, because it doesn’t require you to move at all. It looks like yo
u’re just daydreaming to observers. Listen to a guided meditation recording Student Wellness Center – 11 Jun 18 Guided Audio Recordings"

174391598,"""Psychosis is an umbrella term; it means that an individual has sensory experiences of things that do not exist and/or beliefs with no basis in reality. During a psychotic episode, an individual may experience hallucinations and/or delusions. They may see or hear things that do not exist."" We have definitions for psychosis, schizophrenia, autism, psychedelic trips, ""bad trip"" etc.. But we don't really know what they actually mean. We have an idea of what they mean. Most people know what a car is but they don't know exactly how it works. An engineer or mechanic doesn't even know exactly. Then how are they made right? Well.. in pieces.. some minds control the machine that makes it, the tools, where the pieces are from, what the material is made from.. all together.. and it changes over time.. the software, hardware.. And even if someone did know, their moods change and their thoughts.. so the mental map and physical ideas change with the fabric of time. Reality is just an idea to people. Sometime
s it can cause a ""bad"" feeling to where we try to comprehend how to fix the trip - Which we call life.. Or a dream.. And want to feel better. We interact with people that can make us feel bad - Sometimes even with good intentions or just by accident. No doctor knows the whole human body. You need specialists for the brain, heart, liver, etc... No one mind can understand it all. So we just need to relax and that's why we give hugs to each other. That's all we can do sometimes. We're not crazy. We know more than most people that are stuck, but we are no better and they are no better than us.. Unless it's an idea.. Which is the perception of reality itself to everyone individually."

175992331,"For chest pain, I take 1 mg of Ativan tranquilizer. I almost get into an argument with my cardiologist over that. She declares, it's not a heart problem if Ativan stops the chest pain, that something like Nitroglycerin is supposed to work with true heart pain problems. But I'm telling you, the chest pain can get so bad, it can almost put me on the floor, if it got any worse. So I take an Ativan and the chest pain goes away. Also, when I do exercise like yard work, that night when I lay down to go to sleep, the chest pain is such that I can't go to sleep until I take an Ativan. The next night, I take my regular three 1 mg. of Melatonin from the health food store, also sold in grocery stores in some cases, and I go to sleep without the Ativan. You don't want to get hooked on Ativan. It can be and is addictive. My psychiatrist prescribes it for me. I just take it in extreme situations. Also, I find a heating pad helps my chest pain, so you might want to try that, also. It expands the blood vessels in 
and around the heart. My heating pad is plugged into the wall by my bed, so all I have to do is cut it on when I need it."

175992339,"How are you feeling today A_F? Has your heart settled? What is wave inversion. I have a murmur. Have you ever tried breathing exercises when you get anxiety? They calm you down plus slow down your heart rate and breathing. Try in through the nose and out through the mouth with pursed lips. It is called smelling the roses and blowing out the candles. Do it 10 to 20 times and then see if your pulse has slowed down. In my opinion, worrying about your blood pressure and pulse will only make both of them go up. If you were to have a heart attack, there wouldn't be a lot you would be capable of to stop it other than calling EMS. So I think prevention is the best cure. Find ways to live your life to lower your risk factor. Stress and worry can be killers. So try to not worry so much. Life is short, live it. Try not to worry about the future and past and live in the present. I understand that the first thread on the anxiety forum is the resource thread. It might do you good to take a look if you haven't al
ready. Have a good day A_F... Hugs, _NAME_..."

174391718,"Good find. It was a rough estimate. However, you are free to enlighten us. Yeah some of those “schizoid” killers fell short of the Schizoid Personality Disorder proper. Okay, but do you have an actual critic to formulate? To be more specific, Dr. Stone studied the biographies of serial killers and concluded half were schizoid or loners with mostly schizoid traits . True, the prototypical schizoid is anhedonic, but I don’t see murder and torture counting as “most activities”. The higher a serial killer ranks on the Scale of Evil, the most likely he is to have paraphilias, mainly due to the presence of sexual sadism in the “Most Evil” cases I guess. Personality disorders come and go, it doesn’t mean they stop being relevant. If serial murder and torture isn’t enough to warrant the “antisocial” and “sadistic” labels, then nothing is; but instead, lo and behold, it’s the normal people in their every day life that you view as evil… Talk about turning the screw on its head. 
I don’t know where you saw borderline personality being a lot more co-morbid than schizoid. From my incomplete knowledge, I only know about Russian _PERSON_, but how much can you trust a Soviet Union diagnosis? Then there’s _NAME_, who some psychiatrists have diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic, while others as borderline schizophrenic (an old term for BPD and schizotypal) or even schizoaffective, but he may have been borderline. One of these psychiatrist who interviewed him several times said his personality was too complex to be “psychopathic” (read: narcissistic), which could reflect the fragmented self in Borderline Personality Disorder. _PERSON_ himself claimed he had DID, which resemble the rapid mood swings of borderlines and their splitting of identity. Schizoid use splitting just as much, but being introverted, they don’t necessarily externalize it. If you are so keen on learning, why don’t you do your own research?"

175992370,"Life dealt us a **** hand. It's not our fault our health has put a cap on our real potential in certain areas of our life. But really, how can we enjoy the sweetness of life without the bitter? The downs helps to make the ups just so much better. What's sad to me is when celebrity's children--who have been given everything we could only dream of--but they resort to drugs and alcohol and dwell on a hole inside themselves. In my experience, lifetime winners aren't up to the task many times because they don't have something dark like depression, guilt, shame, or fear to prod them on to better themselves. I'm sure they have some of these negative experiences but hardly nothing profoundly life altering like we experience day in day out. We are forced to stare into the abyss and forced to understand it, to shed light on it, and we are here trying to work on it. 175992384,The answers that were given are spot on. The best way to stop doing something is to “stop doing it”! If you have the capacity to work yourself in higher levels of anxiety then you have the same capacity to build yourself up with positive self talk. It takes 18 to 254 days (depending on our own life experiences) to kick or start a habit! The thing is we have got to want it and just stay at it. It can be especially difficult to speak positive feedback to ourselves when we are feeling overwhelmed and no where even close to positive. Best wishes to you Nanette Depression/Asperger Spectrum/ADHD/Anxiety (Recent bipolar diagnosis)

175992419,"I'm not diagnosed with it and until now I didn't even know, that it has a name. But I definitely have it. I'm incapable of visually imagining anything. When I close the eyes, I see only black and no amount of thinking and mentally focusing on something can make me see an imaginary picture. Most of the time it doesn't affect me at all and I don't miss that ability, because I was born that way, but it is somewhat troublesome, when I'm in a new environment. Due to incapability to visualize things, I also completely lack visual memory, and therefore, unlike most people, I don't remember my way automatically and can then easily get lost even in relatively small places like e.g. inside of a building. In order to find the way back from somewhere, I have to consciously focus on my surroundings, to describe them to myself in words, and then to memorize that description. However, that doesn't mean, that I lack imagination. I cannot see non-existent things and I cannot make myself hear non-existent sounds/voi
ces/music or perceive non-existent smells or touches, either, but I'm perfectly capable to imagine stories. I even used to write stories as a teenager and considering the reactions on my literature teachers, I was quite good at it. I don't think, that aphantasia is a significant impairment, unless one wants to become a painter or a sculptor or something similar. I'm a complete failure at artistic drawing, 5 yrs olds do it better than me, but my technical drawing is unaffected, because I can rely on measurements, numbers (which I also have hard time remembering, but I don't need to, I can write them down), scaling and rules, and don't need to visually imagine the object. And the other hand, my memory for written language is exceptionally good: I still remember books, I've read, when I was 5 yrs old, and learned to understand a few languages just by casually reading on the Internet and without realizing, that I was learning. English is one of them."
175992420,"*external Anyway, to frame it in terms of ""responsibility"", I think another to put it is this: there's a difference between being responsible for a problem and being responsible for the solution. The more common attitude is to assume you're responsible for the problem, which, when you're not, leads you nowhere good. You can always do your best to deal with things or work around them, but you can't simply stop causing a problem you never caused in the first place."

174391861,"If you have much experience of strangers knowing everything about your life - what is it OTHER than the fact they are mindreaders, watching you 24/7, knowing everything you do and plan? And if you seem to think it's a prank to ruin people's brains, hope and bodies than can I suggest we term it an 'evil conspiracy' rather than prank? Here's my experience: You're born, you are stupid, you can't remember your early years, remember some from 5/6 onwards. Some memories perhaps earlier but not many. You get people making sure they become your childhood mates. You have teachers and fellow classmates at around 8/9 hinting at mindreading. You become a little sensitive but you are not evil. You go to another school at 11 or so and then you're forced to deal with a lot more #######4 mindreaders. You notice weirdness in what teachers and classmates say but don't think too much about it. You notice mindgames and people copying your thoughts, or mimicking what you have thought about recently. But again, you're b
usy being a kid and going along, playing sports or listening to music or generally just going along with all that. You get weirdoes mocking you but again you don't think much about it. What you think about at home or are doing at home, the kids talk about and use to bully you. You are probably already used to it. As an adult you would describe it as life having meaning or being special. You enjoy tv, some weird stuff may happen through adverts, like you recently trying to remember a word, and then it appearing in a TV commercial. You get friends on the phone commenting on your physical state of being at that time. In my case, I was paranoid of my mouth making noises and some 'friend' commented on it. You feel weird and walk up the stairs to your bedroom with a weird vibe. They say weird creepy things at other times too. Your sister and mother get you used to mindreading as much as they can, but again you don't notice it until the pressure begins at 20+. It's because they've made life seem normal, and you know 
no better. the mindreading, cloning of your thoughts has become normal. But as a kid, you're going to class, trying to have fun, learn your way through the world. As you get older they begin making it more extreme. Unexpectedly calling you 'ugly' if you are feeling paranoid about your nose or face at that time in life. Your mother knows you're paranoid of your nose so says 'what a big nose' (my nose is not even big). They bully you in ways that you cannot stop, and set you up in ways you don't realise yet. A film makes you cry over the weekend and on the Monday some creepy mindreader (you don't know he's a mindreader until many years later and you're forced to examine every memory) says 'I watched that film on Saturday and it made me cry'. You slowly but surely get weirded out by all this as the years pass. I could go on, but let's cut straight to the present. Cars and mindreaders in them drive past with weird number plates to mess with your mind. You switch the channel on tv or radio, and they immediateely c
lone your thoughts. Astrological websites write down the thoughts you had 5 seconds prior in their daily astrological forecast. Songs use lyrics and pain from your life experience. But you can't prove it. You change the channel on tv and the thing you're gonna say in your head is the exact wording in the script of the film. But it shouldn't be a live film you think in you're head! There are no live films on tv! You go online to schizophrenic chatrooms and forums, and meet more mindreaders ready to abuse you. Showing they are mindreaders yet then claiming you are delusional to mess with your head. You make friendships with girls (I am a hetero guy) and they pretend they like and eventually love you, but keep saying mindreading creepy comments to you, sometimes immediately within 3 seconds. you have no doubt they are mindreaders, but they begin to keep denying it without shame. you end up drinking yourself to death, with no1 in your life, u can't even trust your 'family' or 'mother' or 'sister'. because they've 
given you ample reason to know that they are lying mindreaders, plotting to make your state of mind BAD. through mindgames and horrible evil crap. this is 0.01% (if that) of what I could write). screw all lying mindreaders who pretend there is a point to this. or some good. they are just liars. and many on this site are too. -- Mon Jul 29, 2019 9:41 pm -- I just want to clarify, that is not 0.01% of my mindreading knowledge of what they've done to me. 174391892,"I care. I wish I could help you. I have had schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder for over 20 years. The acute stages are always hard because people typically haven't developed the coping skills to deal with it. Improvement comes with time. Don't condemn yourself for having an illness or having confusion. Things do get better. I now have two Master's degrees and I am looking forward to working full time after many years of part time work. You can definitely get better. I hope you continue to pray and realize that sometimes the hallucinations are extensions of your own thoughts or beliefs. I think schizophrenia also involves dissociation.I think we block our feelings and thoughts which may result in hallucinations. I could be wrong, of course. In any case, try to respect what you feel and take appropriate actions to help yourself. Don't despair. Things do improve. May God be with you."

175992473,"I don't know if I would go to a counsellor. I go to my psychiatrist on a regular basis. For me, I don't think a counsellor would be useful at all. My doctor always knows the right thing to say to calm me down and I always go away from the appointments feeling better. I have rarely found this with doctors, only 2 or 3. For instance, my GI specialist could care less if I live or die and he doesn't do anything to help me. My psychiatrist has helped me more than the GI ""specialist."" Overall, I don't know what a counsellor could do for me. I need someone to talk to who has the education and the knowledge of a psychiatric doctor. Someone who understands how my brain works. 174392016,"I think of my thoughts like arrows that shoot in all directions from my head (Even from the back of my head) in combination with many pictures that do the same. The thoughts can actually BE pictures (Like an Afghan desert with the sand blowing with mountain goats, camels and shamans which gives me a feeling - An encrypted ""thought"") - (Then I start thinking about shamans for example..). But I'd be sitting here in my room, wondering what's happening in the kitchen (How is my mom cooking the chicken?) - I can picture it in my mind and have a map of the whole town and everywhere I've been to, people walking, cars driving.. I think about where my dad is (In Mexico) and I see a map of southern US (California) and a map of Mexico and pools and an underground mine (Because he's a mining consultant). Then I have feelings in relation to all these pictures - I think about the past and crying when he left to go abroad to work or have pictures of the fireflies by the pool in Guatemala (Because he used to wor
k there) and my grandmother was there so I start thinking about her and have a picture of her kitchen - Then I think about all the things I say on Facebook and the feelings of her and how all the feelings of her regrets are starting to get to her now that she's old. I could go on writing for ever and ever. Then there's thoughts about my meds, the house I used to live in, the feelings of depression and agitation so I start thinking about the psych ward.. (Ok I'll stop now but you get the point..) I think I mostly think in pictures idk. Then there's things that I SEE in real life and what I'm focusing on. I honestly am more entertained by the pictures in my head (ADHD and imagination - Autism? Idk). Paranoia can be a certain feeling of a sort of anxiety where my thoughts are stronger and the pictures are weaker.. idk.. With Vyvanse, if I take two, I'd be sitting on my phone and yknow how I said my thoughts shoot from all directions in my head? With two Vyvanses, it all narrows down to what I SEE and the thought
s shoot in directions from my eyes to what I see and I can then focus and things are processed faster because I have more dopamine which provides enough stimulation to not want to get stimulation from ""daydreaming"" and go off into a tangent of thought and picture hell. I'm on Vyvanse right now but just one. One Vyvanse provides a happy medium (I'm supposed to take one). And I think that's why Vyvanse can cause psychosis in anyone that takes too much. Antipsychotics are different and lessen everything in the brain so all thoughts and pictures are diminished but the opposite of antipsychotics (Psychedelics) cause more pictures and thoughts which manifest themselves as visual and auditory hallucinations (Which is why they're called ""Hallucinogens"").. People with autism, ADHD and/or schizophrenia are creative.. Depression is ""Lack of serotonin"" and psychedelics are serotonin analogues so it's like increasing serotonin which makes you feel ""Happy"" because you have many pictures.. Anyways I'm feeling less a
pathetic cuz the weed wore off. The weed is another story for another day XD"

I would urge caution when listening to music, and the higher the pitch, the more rough it can be on your ears. Outside, if their is noise from car traffic, you may tend to push up the volume on your ear phones. But you probably shouldn't do tha

175992656,"Call ahead to local pcps and see if they will offer a payment plan. I had one for a while that would bill me at Medicare level price which is less than most insurance would charge for a visit and they billed me so I had a little time to pay it off. It wasn’t great for them I’m sure but I did appreciate the kindness. Many are willing to do payment plans. Might be a good idea either way to find a pcp that’s willing to work with you, that way if you ever have an issue you will know where to go and you might avoid an even more costly urgent care or ER bill. I personally feel like just the concept of not knowing who to turn to magnifies anxiety quite a bit. Post Edited (_USER_ID_) : 6/8/2019 5:34:32 PM (GMT-6)"

174392162,"This quote: ""I wake up thinking lots of weird stuff at a fast pace"" Is a large part of what MANIA is -- the common term is ""racing thoughts"". Something like lithium or depakote or any other mood stabilizer can help, talk to your doctor (you have one, right?) and explain the racing thoughts thing.. If there are 3.2 million schizophrenics (google) please consider on top of that BIPOLAR symptoms, and you'll realize there are far more BIPOLAR people (or schizoaffectives; bipolar and schizoaffective are similar) who experience MANIA or HYPOMANIA. 175992713,"""Open Awareness Meditation, also known as “open attention,” “open monitoring,” or “soft focus,” is a form of mindfulness meditation in which you allow the many things present in your consciousness (sounds and other sensory input, as well as your thoughts and emotions) to arise in your awareness and then naturally fall away as they are replaced by different sounds, thoughts, etc. This kind of meditation is considered a “yin” practice."" Whenever I feel exhausted from focusing, I lie down in bed, put the covers over me and just BE.. Because of the Vyvanse maybe, I don't actually fall asleep - Sometimes I do if I'm really tired.. But not when I usually do it @ around 4-6pm. I lie there for 30-60 minutes and just think and experience.. The reason is that it doesn't require a lot of focus just ""Soft focus"" which is what I really need during those times. I get focus exhaustion. It's like a form of sleep and changed the brain waves by giving the mind time to relax. Then when I'm done, I 
feel much more aware, clear minded, happier, focused, relaxed etc"

175992741,"Many people with various mental health diagnoses get distracted or board easily -- especially during routine tasks or paperwork. This can make it difficult to stay focused at work. Try these tips: 1. Break up big tasks into smaller tasks. 2. Between tasks, take a walk or get fresh air. 3. Take notes in meetings. ( I got permission to use a tape recorder so don't be afraid to ask I simply said I didn't want to miss a word that was said ) LOL yea I know.... Give these a try and let us know what works if you will please. OR If you have other suggestions to help please SHARE them with everyone! Tc, _PERSON_"

175992743,"Funny story where faith ended me up. It turned out that I got no manager position after the last one (also I didn't look desperately for one, I even canceled one myself). So maybe my (according to the doctors) schizoid nature dragged me into this: I'm an external software developer now, detached from the other (internal) developers (not even in the same room) and if I want to I can spend a whole day without saying one word to someone else. For real, I could - in this role - just login to the computer, type, and leave in the evening, and everything'd be perfect. Well, I do go to lunch with the internal colleagues, but I don't have to. Very schizoid position, isn't it ? Even worse (or better), I sleep 3 nights in another city and see my family less. Now I'm afraid of loosing all the social skills again, that I learned (the hard way) during my last manager job. Thinks like smiling at people when talking to them The good thing is, in the manager job I got continuous negative feedback. Even though my bu
siness results were objectively and measurable far above average. But no one cares about results on that level, even worse, standing out with good results cause other managers to start fighting you. What counts on that level is making alliances, faking reputation (of oneself and the next upper managers), hiding errors, playing dirty games etc. And with schizoid distance I could only loose in that manipulation games.. So this negative feedback from the NPD/ASD/HPD/machiaw. managers creeps stopped. Instead I'm way ahead of schedule with my technology and get ... well ... no feedback. Which feels like positive feedback now, after stepping out of the last shark tank Question for me is now: - Do I accept being a bad manager (though my decisions were great and I led with great empathy, freedom and trust - so I'm good for EBIT and only bad for selfish political manager netwoks). Do I give up and have a great time with a talk-to-no-one PC job. (Way better payed by the way than the manager job for some special reasons
.) - Or do I NOT accept the vote of the prior looser company (they're loosing so much market share by the way that they say they're in danger, and claim themselves that cultural weakness is one of the cause for dying, by the way). Or how can I find out ? I think deep in me, although I really enjoy a day coding and talking to no one. I enjoy this a lot. But deep in me, I'm lonely on the PC and would prefer leading a team again. Shaping culture, reaching goals together, giving freedom, being proud of my staff's results when they are successful BECAUSE I gave them trust and freedom ... Maybe I need to found a start-up for finding out. There I can lead without playing axix-b-who's-the-weakest-manager-fake-guy-with-the-most-blown-up-fake-self-esteem-fake-games. Or I say, f... off world, I like coding, the money is more than ok, no stress, but with the downside of mutating more and more into a nerd. I noticed that my voice got much more silent when I speak. My body language changed. I started being able to see in t
he dark ... no"

175992768,"Our memories are unreliable. Also when we are kids we get terrified by very simple things so it doesn’t have to be sexual abuse to register in your mind as such. 175992795,"Hi HW Family. I hope you are all having a good day. So I am coming to the end of my CAT (Cognitive Analytical Therapy) next Monday is my last session and I have to see that I have learnt and got more out of this therapy than any other therapy I have done in the past so can highly recommend CAT to you all. Today I saw a new Psychiatrist and the appointment went really well he's completely different to my old Psychiatrist in terms of he believes more in talking therapy than medications. We jointly decided that I was taking to much medication and now that I have done so well in therapy I should be more able to deal with my mental health without all the meds. I am currently taking 15mg Olanzapine, 60mg Prozac and 4mg Valium we decided that I would wean of the Olanzapine first which will be a slow taper over the period of a month gradually reducing the dosage until i'm off it completely. I have another appointment with him in a months time to see how i'm getting on and if all has gone well then I will a
im to stop the Valium which will just leave me on the Prozac but he has a few different alternatives to that which he think may work better for me. So I am aiming to go from 3 medications to 1 I would be lying if I said I wasn't feeling anxious about this but I really won't to do it as I'm sick of taking all these meds. 175992806,"My barometer for how I’m doing is often my tolerance...if someone at the store says I can’t return a forty dollar item because of their policy, I fly off the handle, usually not at them, but clearly attitude of injustice, then it follows me around for awhile and affects my relationships or energy. That’s a good indicator, I’m not in alignment or balanced. It’s time for reflecting on my diet, device use, sleep, addictions, etc. that’s a sign for me to up My meditations I do online ( getting support that way helps to hold me accountable), my journaling, being in nature or near water. Etc. it’s different for everyone. What is it that bring you back to you. What bring you calm in body and mind. Your introspection of how you keep meeting up with your trauma one way or another is great. Noticing our patterns is step one. Asking for help is part of this too. So congrats on both of those. And I’m cheering you on. We are so lucky to have so many inspiring folks out there, comedians, teachers
, fellow meditators as well as flower essences to support systems in me that aren’t balanced for whatever reason ( Covid, health, work) That’s what I know to do. 174392376,"125mg would get me high 25 times. I'm EXTREMELY sensitive to weed.. Especially edibles.. 5mg gets me really stoned.. I find it unpleasant although I have really cool thoughts and ideas.. But everyones different - Also depending on the time of day, your set (Mind state - Like how your thoughts and feelings are, etc) and setting (Environment, lighting, air temperature). It's a very spiritual thing.. And over time, people smoke joints like cigarettes every day. Like 15 of them a day. Edibles are debated to be like a psychedelic because the THC converts into a certain type (I forget what it's called) but it's 7x or something more potent than smoked THC and has psychedelic effects, agonizing 5HT2A receptors. Your antipsychotics antagonize 5HT2A receptors so it's possible that you sort of had a psychedelic experience and then need a couple of days for your tolerance to go down so you can be high again. It does increase dopamine too which makes you focused, feel good, does things with appetite, etc.. It t
akes 2 weeks for dopamine to recharge after a couple months worth of using - Two years or more for long term use.. Also, address your psychological pain! Spirits, psychosis, trauma, etc.. Weed can be interesting but not good if you're trying to stabilize yourself on antipsychotics. Even I tell myself this.. I'm like ""Man I can smoke weed I don't have schizophrenia"" and then I go psychotic and while high I'm like ""Oh **** I feel sort of autistic like I'm God and I'm going to die.. I'm panicking.."".. Sometimes weed helps me focus and relax.. It just depends on my set and setting.. My mom says not to smoke weed but sometimes I believe she's apart of the conspiracy or just went along with the schizophrenia label and there's something deeper that I think of.. Like everything can be analyzed and philosophical - Right or wrong - It doesn't matter.. We can do what we want although there's consequences.. Life happens. We get high, we cry, we die then we fly."

175992882,"Folks have been arguing about this issue forever. Actually, we have two issues 1. Change from the original (patent protected) version to a generic. 2. Differences between generics (one manufacturer versus another) Note also that while the active ingredient of a 'pill' may well be the same, the formulation (of the pill) by different manufacturers may be different. The FDA is supposed to certify generics and the plants where they are made, but may not always do the job, unfortunately. As an aside, I take three prescription drugs (for cardiac issues) and have not noticed a difference when the insurance system forced a change from the original (non-generic) forms to generic ones, other than the shape or color of the pills."

174392408,"I recovered from a major psychosis last year. I had never been through anything like it before and never expected to ever go through something like it. This here is a list of things I thought/believed while in my psychosis: 1. The main delusion was that I believed people were watching me somehow. At first I thought people were just watching me through my webcam and/or cell phone camera. Then it evolved into me believing there were cameras in the walls ALL OVER my house. Then my delusions got much bigger - I thought perhaps there was a satellite camera in space capturing my every move. I had classic ""_NAME_ Show"" Syndrome. Like the movie The _NAME_ Show, I believed my life was a sort of television show and that people had been watching me every day for years. 2. At first I thought only one person was stalking me - and then wanting to kill me for some reason. Then it evolved into thinking the ILLUMINATI was targeting me. Or perhaps some kind of murder group on the Dark Web. 3. I was a member of a d
ifferent Internet forum. I became convinced the members of this forum were not who they claimed to be. I thought the forum was a ""front"" for something more evil and sinister. Again, either Dark Web stuff or Illuminati or something evil. 4. I became convinced that THE ENTIRE INTERNET was devoted to watching my life unfold and that everything written in the media and shown on TV -- commercials, shows, news, etc -- was CRYPTICALLY about me. I began seeing the number ""12"" everywhere and was convinced ""12"" was a secret Illuminati code number. This was so weird that to this day, I still get worried when I see someone say ""12"" online. 5. I thought that _NAME_ was like an avatar being used to represent me, and that I was the real President of the United States, and that every move I made dictated how the world stage was going to unfold. 6. I thought that comic strips and newspaper articles cryptically were created to speak of and talk about me. 7. Biggest delusion -- I thought someone, or a group of people, s
nuck into my room at night, chloroformed me while I was asleep, and injected me with millions of cancer cells while I slept. I thought I had cancer growing in my body. Brain cancer, lung cancer, male breast cancer, testicular cancer - I thought I was going to get it all. And I thought it was going to start showing itself in the springtime -- when it started to get warm and hot outside. I was deathly afraid that heat was going to cause cancer to pop out of my body - that I would get sick and die in the summer months, be dead by fall. I was convinced that people on the internet everywhere knew this and were cryptically talking about it. 8. I thought my family were aliens from outer space intent to kill me. 9. I thought I had ""handlers"" that followed me everywhere I went, and lived on my street in a different house (I never knew which one). There's other stuff, but I can't think of it all, and it's been awhile since I had these delusions. I had no health insurance and wanted to get checked out by a doctor. I c
ommitted myself to a mental hospital last year and stayed only a week. I was prescribed Abilify and Prozac (later Rexulti instead of Abilify). MY DELUSIONS WENT AWAY. Not in the hospital, but after I came home. Strangely, they seemed to get better once I started the Prozac. I never believed I was crazy. I didn't expect psychiatry to work. BUT IT DID. And I'm a sane person again today."

174392513,"Hello jc77.I have been on Abilify for 8 months.I started out with 2 mgs per day and it got to a point that I wanted to crawl out of my skin..After going through multiple meds to go with the Lamotrigine ,the Abilify was like a last resort.My pharmacist told me to cut the 2 mgs into 4 sections and take one section until I can tolerate it and then continue going up.It would take about three weeks on each quarter of 2 mgs for my body to adjust to that dose .After about 12 weeks I was finally able to take 2 mgs per day and feel good.I have never felt better than now with the 300 mgs of Lamotrigine and 2 mgs of Abilify.It was certainly worth the time and effort to let my body slowly adjust to the Abilify,Good luck and I hope you find the proper cocktail of meds for you."

175993007,"Yes, exactly. I don't think it's physical, unless you feel very fatigued. Anemia? Low protein? See a doctor to rule all that out if it's really bothering you. Are you on any meds? SSRI's make my avolition worse. Some good signs that it's not all lost. Do you ever have isolated moments when you feel ambitious or are able to get engaged in things? If even for a short time? If so, try to figure out why. Work backwards and try to think of any triggers (good triggers) that gave you this ambition. What do you think put you in that state of mind? Proper sleep hygiene is important. Are you getting enough sleep? When I'm backed up on sleep it makes all these symptoms worse. For me, what sucks is that when I'm at work I think about all the stuff I want to do and get very psyched up about doing them. Then when I get home.....nothing. It's like there's something in the air. I've been trying to use the law of inertia: things in motion tend to stay in motion. Doing stuff even when I don't feel like it, hoping so
mething will click. Keep fighting it. I think if you don't fight it, it will get worse."

We encourage you to check other discussions in this community about ""senior citizen"" depression and geriatric depression. You can start by typing your search terms in the box near the magnifying glass at the top right side of the page or by clicking the links below. Search: ""senior citizen"" depression Search: geriatric depression Our partner for this community, Mental Health America, also provides resources on their website including information about treatment options, guided recovery techniques, and self-help toolkits. This information can be found at the following links. Mental Health America: Finding Help for Myself Mental Health America: Recovery and Support Mental Health America: DIY Tools In addition, you may want to check out our iFred community. 175993136,"I love what you said about how you are moving on to healing instead of coping. With that attitude, you are already on your way with so much that you've dealt with, but you will succeed. Also, ex-pat communities, if you're part of one or you can find one, maybe they would know therapists/doctors that can be helpful. As you've said, you are willing to take control, but you may still need help, and there's absolutely nothing wrong with that. Maybe a community like that where you are can help you find the person you need to talk to. An article about Post Traumatic Stress - What is It had a few suggestions on what can be done in the meantime. Following a routine. If you are spiritually inclined, this would include a spiritual routine. Many have found comfort in the Psalms reading about others who have been afflicted and turning those same thoughts to prayer. If you are not spirit
ually inclined, a routine that works for you involving self-care. Do you enjoy exercise or walking, riding a bike, swimming, hiking, etc. I can only imagine the beautiful vistas there must be everywhere in Thailand. Maybe making a beautiful destination a frequent stop for you to visit, a place to be calm, meditate might be helpful. ""Although alcohol and drugs may give promise of temporary relief, they soon make matters worse. They usually contribute to social isolation, rejection of the people who want to help, workaholism, uncontrolled anger, uncontrolled or overcontrolled eating, or other self-destructive behavior."" This was quoted in the article and I'll just leave it there for you to think about. Obviously, you have to make the final decisions, but I just wanted to add how substances can affect someone and even make things worse. I hope any of this even to a small degree was helpful. And I wish you well on your journey to mental well-being."

175993153,"You have soul exhaustion. You need a relaxing break and good meds. All meds are different. The chemical structures have no moral value.. Like meth for example as Desoxyn for medication.. Antipsychotics are derived from antihistamines or benzos. All sleep meds are benzo or derivatives of them.. Adrenochrome is what the elites drink from childrens blood and mix it with DMT - But that's not likely real. People have whacky ideas about everything. Just know that as long as you feel in control, you're ok - If you think you're in control, you're most likely to be ok still - As long as you control the anxiety, mood etc with coping mechanisms, meds, support.. Mania displays symptoms of ADHD - And people with ADHD get mad abuse. I was abused by teachers in school and it probably contributed to my depression because I wasn't focused and just wanted to be happy - Rejected structure and moderation of things. I was the most popular in middle school though for being funny. Good humour, no darkness stuff.. You don
't have bad vibes, negativity etc.. Which can all be managed in anyone as well - You are a good soul. A tired soul though.. Study the mathematics in moderation, make way for expressing the mania through writing, journaling, maybe art.. The bipolar mind is full of emotional pain - Schiz mind is like a _USER_ID_ trip and is dysphoric and painful thoughts."

175993177,"I don‘t know if I can be helpful here. But I had some similar issues with my dad, who didn’t care about my eating disorder and it was hell for me. It can cause even more distress to your son, if he isn‘t taken seriously. What I always wished my dad would do, is to do some research on my _NAME_, read books, search the internet or join some groups for parents with children who have mental illness etc. I don‘t think you coddle, if you try to help your son and try to understand him. Motivation issues aren‘t rare in depression... and I don‘t know... but I wouldn‘t force someone out off the house if they aren’t mentally stable, I would rather try to talk to them about their problems and maybe even suggest therapy. Sometimes it takes time for young adults to find their path and what they want to do after school. And sometimes 
it really helps to give them the time they need, to try things out first, before they can settle on one job or school. And one thing, I think is really important, is to also give them time to work on their mental illness and to truly understand themselves what‘s going on with them."

174392857,"• I am new, and I’m looking to vent, get educated, coping skills, advice, ANYTHING.! This will be very long and I apologize but my therapist told me about this site today, and I really need to tell my story.! • I have 4 beautiful, sweet, loving and caring children. (When they won’t to be. Lol.) I’m 33yrs old and a single mom. I work full time and provide for my kids. My middle son plays baseball, and my daughter is about to start playing Volleyball and Softball. We are very much a sports family.! So with that out the way, here is my issue: • I have a 15yr old son that has been in and out of Mental Health Facilities since he was 6yrs old. Just these past 2yrs he has actually been in and out of placements to get him away from his family. When he was 6yrs old he saw his father beating on me. From that day till now, it was like a switch went off in his brain and he has never been the same. He started acting out in very odd ways. He started setting the bed, sleep walking, was using the bathr
oom in parts of his room or in the hallway. He started hurting our animals in a bad way. He killed (suffocated) our 2 baby kittens at the time. Started getting fascinated with fire. Becoming mean and harmful to his brother (4yrs old at the time) and his sister (3yrs old at the time.) The older that he became the worse his behavior got. The more intense he was becoming. Throughout the years, he started hurting his siblings in a way that, I had to move them in my room and we had to sleep with a dead bolt on my bedroom door and a dresser in front of it. • Fast forwarding a little now and the past 2yrs. He has started coming after me these past few years. He has hurt me by physically putting his hands on me and punching on me. I have permanent nerve damage in my ring thumb from where he latched on with his teeth and would not let go until he heard the police sirens coming. He has stabbed my middle son several times. He has made very sexual threats to his 12yr old sister. He has put his hands on his sister and y
anks her hair so hard that he throws her to the ground. He has gone after neighborhood kids with knives. He still hurts our animals. He has set fires in my home several times. He has no remorse, no empathy, no emotion of any sort besides anger. He refuses to go to school. He hates authority of any kind. He hates me and his siblings. Currently, he is in a placement about 2hrs from where I live, and while being there, he has set 2 fires, destroys others property, punches holes and purposely tries to break his hand, cusses out the staff there. The first week of August the therapist there called and told me that because he wasn’t able to hit anything, he went outside for outside time, and stuck his hand/arm (up to his elbow) in a fire ant bed. Never moved it out, never even made a flinch that the ants were biting him. The staff had to forcibly move his arm out of it because he wouldn’t do it himself. When they tried to explain to him how dangerous it was, they said he shrugged his shoulders and said whatever. 
With no expression on his face, no regard whatsoever.! He is constantly in trouble with the law, and smokes weed. When I try to punish him, make him do chores, or hold him accountable for his actions or behaviors, he attacks me. Most of the time, to get back at me, he goes after his brother and sister. He hurts my children. It’s not just occasionally. It’s all the time. • I’m very frustrated and angry with our county Mental Health.! They haven’t really ever done their job with my son.! He is a prime example of a kid that’s fallen through the cracks. I truly and deeply, in my heart feel like my son is a sociopath. Maybe I am wrong, idk. I’m not a doctor. I started reaching Anti Social Personality Disorder.! His doctors say that he shows A LOT of those signatures. The problem is, they won’t label him because he is a teen. I know that he is a kid, and his brain is still developing, and there’s no telling which way he may go. Kinda like with Bi Polar Disorder. He is taking meds that target a few 
known Disorders. (schizophrenia, Bi Polar, Anti Social Personality Disorder.) • The place he is at will be discharging him in a month.! I’m terrified of him. My kids are terrified of him. I’ve lost countless of jobs because of him, because I was not allowed to leave my kids home with him. I’ve lost 2 homes because of him. I’ve been with my job now for a year, and I’m so scared that when he comes back I’m going to lose it. That happens, I lose my beautiful home, my car. My children lose their home. It’s not right.! My oldest is a very big manipulator and all his doctors see it and have told me.! He also has a Learning Disability. At 15yrs old his IQ is only 67. This is everything my son is diagnosed with right now: ADD/ADHD Combined, Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Conduct Disorder, Mood Dysregulation Disorder, PTSD. • What do I do.? How do I educate myself enough to know how to handle a kid like this. If he truly has Anti Social Personality Disorder, then how do I discipline a kid like that.? 
How do I keep him away from kids and myself.? How do I protect him.? Should I continue to demand answers from the place he’s at.? How do I protect my other children.? 175993245,"Hey _PERSON_, It's worth waiting for a couple of weeks. SSRIs usually show their full benefits after 2 months or so. 174393049,"Hi (new here, but I deal with this) -- I'm one of those people who DID research a lot (especially when on wrong meds) into 'targetted individuals' and 'stimdust' and that kind of thing (technologies which COULD very well explain what i was experiencing, and still do).. Now I'm on risperidone again, and CALM and mostly NOT REACTING to it (even internally), but when i'm in crowds like in a loud restaurant, or even not in crowds like walking in a hotel hallway/elevator, i hear people who know too much about what i'm thinking. It's difficult to explain if you haven't dealt with it, but I just learned this is what they mean by 'thought broadcasting'. An example from more than a year ago, in a crowd, or restaurant, I'd notice people staring at their smart phones and reacting (commenting/repeating/mocking) as if they were reading real time transcripts of my ANXIOUS (at the time) thoughts. On top of that, because my head is 'normally quiet', the fact that i am having so many thoughts lead me to believe tha
t these thoughts are ""inserted"" (psych terminology - thought insertion). This is schizophrenia forum, i have 'schizoaffective' diagnosis which features both schizophrenia and bipolar in my case. On my current meds, this is happening FAR LESS OFTEN than on my previous two med tries, but it still happens."

175993463,"Yes, I take citalopram, a close relative of Lexapro. It takes a while for things to settle down and for the good effects of the medication to settle in. I remember having continued anxiety symptoms for a month or two after starting citalopram, but didn't have the tingling you describe. Do you feel any less anxiety? It should be starting to diminish by now. If not, it's wise to check in with your PCP for advise. In my case, it took several months for the medication to take full effect, but my anxiety was noticeably less within a couple of months. Sometimes, Lexapro (or citalopram) may be interacting with other meds. Again, check with your PCP or pharmacist. At the time I started taking citalopram I wasn't on any other meds (now I am, but none interfere with the anxiety-reducing effect of citalopram). Take care and hang in there. Let us know how things are going with this med."

175993469,"What do you consider intellectually stimulating? As mentioned for me, it depends on what piques my interest at the time. Of course, politics, religion and science (random new information) have some sort of mainstay. The issue with religion is that it's hard to debate faith and science is just fact as much as we know right now. Of course, some of those science facts are pretty darn good but how healthy is an egg? Yes, moderation is key. In politics, it's always interesting to see how someone arrived at an idea and stuck with it. Of course, the problem with politics is whether they arrived there on fact, faith or their ass. So really, the only thing intellectually stimulating is someone presenting an idea, some data to back it up, I haven't seen it yet but it somehow interests me. Who is better at that than the collective mind of the internet?"

175993500,"Journaling is a great idea and distracting yourself as much as possible with a positive activity, something that brings you joy is recommended. An article I read on this very topic of Negative Emotions had a good checklist for replacing intrusive thoughts with positive emotions ""The first step toward controlling negative emotions is: Identify the negative thoughts. Second: Work on correcting the negative thoughts. If, for instance, you were thinking, ‘I never do anything right,’ substitute this with, ‘I’m just like everyone else; I do many things right, but I make my share of mistakes too.’ Do not expect to feel better immediately after making this correction (although you may), and do not get stuck mentally debating the matter. Just make the affirmation and move on to the next step. The third step is to work at dismissing the troublesome thought from your mind. Try to push it out as forcefully and confidently as you would the thought of committing a serious crime. While you may be able 
to do this with strong mental effort, of immense help in doing so is the fourth step: Get absorbed in something else, something upbuilding."" I like what it goes on to say later about how if there was music playing (they used the illustration of a phonograph but of course those don't exist anymore) and a song came on that we don't like, we wouldn't expect the phonograph/record player/CD player/music app, lol, to do better. We would simply skip or change the song. That is the same thing we can do in our heads when a negative thought enters, banish it as quickly as possible and replace it with something positive. It doesn't have to be earth-shattering. Just looking at the butterflies in my garden makes me smile as an example. Trying a new recipe, playing a new game, dancing to your favorite music or singing, playing an instrument, exercise, reading, anything that you feel can distract you and at the same time lift your spirits, go for it. I hope some of this info helped."
