175993555,"Hello, I am new here and have never been on any kind of forum, so this is a little bit scary. I am currently taking Cymbalta and Wellbutrin to help with my anxiety and depression, as well as Klonopin for when I have panic attacks. However, I am running out of medication (I only have enough for 9 more days), and I do not have a way of getting a refill or a new prescript ion. Last fall I moved away from home for college, which means that I had to transfer my Medicaid information to a new county. However, I ran into many problems while trying to do so and I was never able to get healthcare in the new city where I go to school. Thankfully, at the time a psychiatrist I was seeing back home gave me enough medication to last for 3 months to give me time to transfer my Medicaid before my case was closed. Those 3 months came and went and although I tried reaching out, I wasn't able to access mental health services. And I ran out of medication. I remember how awful the withdrawal symptoms were and I am reall
y afraid of falling back into that dark place. I got very depressed to the point where I could no longer get out of bed. I was really nauseous, weak, barely eating and would get these weird shock-like sensations through my whole body very often. I was also very suicidal and very depressed, and I was finally convinced by my very worried mother to go to a crisis center on campus to seek help because I felt like I could not go on. I told the psychiatrist there about my entire situation and my history with mental illness. They gave me a refill on my medication but I never got a follow up appointment and have not seen a doctor since. Now, I am back home for the summer, but because my case was cancelled when I moved away and since I do not permanently live here anymore I couldn't get mental health services at the place where I used to for so many years. I was told that if my case were to be re opened, it would be 2-3 months before I would be able to see a doctor and by then it will be too late. I am afraid of going 
through withdrawal symptoms again and I am so tired of taking medication. I have been taking medication for my anxiety and depression since I was 12 years old and I am really afraid of having to deal with this for the rest of my life. I do not want to have to take medication forever. I have been wanting to get off it, but if that were to happen I'd have to gradually wean off the medication with lower doses and such. I have tried visiting and calling different health centers nearby but I am always told that they cannot offer me services, there is no doctor who can give such high doses on such controlled drugs, or they just give me a phone number to call which will usually end up with them giving me another phone number to call because they cannot help me. I feel very stuck and anxious and I do not know what to do anymore. I was wondering if anyone has any suggestions on how to deal with withdrawal symptoms from these medications? 175993569,"Hi I found this post really interesting and identified with a lot of what people have said. I was diagnosed with Autism and do have a 'social mask' which is what people see when I have to interact. This social mask has changed over the years so if I got bored with pretending to have one personality. I'd move and start again with a new one for the next place. I've always had a rich fantasy life but when younger I had limited time to indulge due to work/study commitments and living with others so other people were around so I couldn't get lost in the fantasy. (I like to pace around and act the fantasy out a bit, talking to whoever I'm talking to in the fantasy). Due to health problems later in life I had to give up work and spent alot of time alone,spending 4-6 hours a day fantasising,but able to 'come out' to get things done when needed. I also had a dog that kept me 'grounded me in reality' and made sure I got out everyday. The agoraphobia is worse due to years of isolation and although I can manag
e getting the dog out when no-one else is about. I struggle if I have to go into town or a supermarket/shopping centre or social event like a family party/wedding etc so for me it's more about how much noise there is and how many people rather than just 'going outside'. (as I'll happily walk the dog miles at 5-6 am when we have the field/woods/parks to ourselves). I have several persona's and sometimes use different one's in different situations.I'm not sure if I have full DID (Dissociative Identity Disorder) or if its just a very advanced form of 'autistic masking'. Either way I dissociate a lot from anything and everything I either don't like or don't want to deal with. Sometimes I will fantasize about dealing with a situation, decide what's needed and create a persona/alter-ego who then deals with the situation in real life. Unlike DID though my persona's/alter don't have their own likes/dislikes/lives. They have all being created by me sometimes from memories of myself at an age I liked, sometimes after g
etting obsessed with a certain person or a disability they had (I'd start by pretending to be them only in fantasy then become them in real life). I had no attachment to the alters or anyone I made friends with in real life when I was that 'alter' and frequently just moved if I felt people were getting too close to discovering 'my secret' and started again as someone else in another place. I don't know if this is typical of SPD? I haven't found anyone else with Autism who has ever done these things to the same degree to assume I must also have some other kind of personality disorder or mental health condition on top of the autism I had as a child? I'd sign my name but I'm not entirely sure which alter has written all this!"

175993596,"Hello, I deal with a similar situation. I am in Menopause now. I've dealt with anxiety and depression my entire life. It's hard for people to understand mental health issues within a person, for it is hidden well at times. My suggestion is find articles that relate to your situation and ask your husband to read those and it might help him release it's real what your going through and then might be able to be emotionally available and supportive to you during the difficult times."

And, you could be married to her not a year or two, but 10 years, then 20. That would be worse. It hangs in the balance. All the talk to now has been about her, how many chairs she’s thrown at you, how many parties you two left because of her temper. But what about you? Who’s the guy in all of this? Why? As I say, it can get worse, like, you don’t leave and she “forgets” to take her birth control pills. You’ll look back to these days as the “happy years.” Leave her and you leave your kid, take your choice. Plus the kid grows up in that environment. I know about this because I married a person just like her. While we were dating, I had clues, also, like she told me of sex she was having with other guys, but I reasoned, well, we’re not married. Also, I didn’t have the strength to leave, and I didn’t want to be by myself. 
If you have the strength, that would be my suggestion. She’s going to be hard to live with for the next 10 years, but the question is, are you going to be living with her? If you are, you’ll see it close-up and come back here complaining about it. If you’re not, you won’t see it and it won’t matter. There are some situations that can’t be helped. But what you can do is leave the situation. I think she is borderline personality syndrome. It stems from abuse in childhood, mostly sexual. You need to look that up. Again, I know about this because that’s what my wife was. They’re cure rate is not real high. Medicine does not help. The question is, can you help yourself by leaving? Have you ever heard her say she was sexually abused? Has she every hinted at such? I once tried to help a person who was on drugs by asking them to go to a counselor/psychiatrist but she always had excuses for not going. I finally realized, I have to get away from that. I cannot help her. The only person who can help is a 
counselor who sees them in an office for 30 minutes and then says, “I’ll see you next month.” If they get well, fine, but if they don’t, at least the counselor didn’t waste his time. You don't have an office. You can't tell them, ""Your 30 minutes is up. I'll see you next month."" You could waste 10 or 20 years, not 30 minutes. So, the question is not only her behavior, but yours, as in, why are you staying? Do you have the confidence to leave, if you decide that? Do you have things you can go to?"

That's a random _NAME_ out of one of _PERSON_ operas. For all that _PERSON_ did for the classical music world, he's not really seen in the mainstream as being a major composer. _PERSON_ did more for the classical music world than any other composer I'd argue. There are four things he did, one is somewhat commonly known, and the other three aren't. 1. He taught _PERSON_/ Everyone and their brother knows who _PERSON_ is. Odds are you've heard a _PERSON_ piece in a movie or on a commercial. Everyone knows this https://youtu.be/XeT17YeUj5k?t=775 _PERSON_ had more than one teacher, but he credited _PERSON_ for teaching him the most. 2. _PERSON_ taught tutored _PERSON_ too By the time _PERSON_ and _PERSON_ met, _PERSON_ didn't need mu
ch tutoring, he was already highly successful and critically acclaimed. However, _PERSON_, being much more experienced, took _PERSON_ under his wing and taught him what he knew. _PERSON_ would later go on to compose what are commonly referred to as ""The Six Haydn Quartets"". He wrote these for _PERSON_, inspired by _PERSON_. He got them published and sent them to _PERSON_ with a letter, stating... Speaking of string quartets... 3. _PERSON_ is the father of the string quartet and the symphony I'm putting the last two into one. _PERSON_ had over 100 symphonies, close to 80 string quartets, and (I believe) the founder of both of these styles. _PERSON_ job, like most composers of that time, was to compose music for a prince. However, _PERSON_ wasn't allowed much contact with the outside world, including his family. He wasn't allowed to listen to music. This is where _PERSON_ famous quote of ""I was forced to become original,"" comes from. Almost every major composer after _PERSON_ had string quartets and symphon
ies. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, you name them, with they had at least one of the two. _PERSON_ also composed a living crap ton of ""Baryton trios"". What's a Baryton you ask? It's a string instrument that one of the princes he worked for played. You've never heard of it because literally no one other than _PERSON_ ever used it. No one takes their kids to the music store for them to learn the _PERSON_. You look at someone like _NAME_, who experimented with literally everything. ""Oh, I can make a concerto out of that? Well okay then, sign me up!"" _PERSON_ didn't it to that level, but he had some wild pieces that haven't been done since. I don't know what else to say. I think I'm done. Here's a _PERSON_ trio for you, with a video of someone playing it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQmeHq67k68"

175993755,"Hi there ""fried pickles""! I LOVE that name! I , too , have panic attacks. They are soooo scary! Here's a few things I do to try to get over them: 1. This is going to sound silly, but trust me it works. Force yourself to laugh. Call up someone and ask them to tell you a funny story, or go online for jokes to read, or just simply pretend to laugh- like you are an actor in a movie. When you laugh, your body releases serontonin, and endorphins, and they will relax you. They are the ""feel good"" hormones. I have called friends ahead of time to ask them to prepare a joke or story for me in case I call for one in the future. It is hilarious what some people will say. 2. Freeze ahead of time, an orange or a baggie full of ice. When you feel an attack coming on, go into the freezer and grab it and hold onto it. Your mind focuses on the coldness and moves on from the panic. If anyone else has other ideas, please share! Blessings to you all. _NAME_"

175993780,"Cognitive therapy is a time-limited, results-oriented approach that is most effective when there’s a specific problem or goal to work on. Cognitive Remediation (CR) uses individualized drills and group bridging sessions to improve functioning in targeted areas of cognition such as attention, memory, and problem-solving. Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT) is a form of psychotherapy that helps people understand how their thoughts influence their feelings and behavior. Click on the links to read more concerning these diagnoses."

Then Covid-19 hit and as a firefighter with 2 children he was estranged from them for weeks when he thought he had been exposed and was mentally battling whether to see them at all because of it all...he broke up with me a little after Easter. I had to push him to talk to his mom and seek a counselor, which he's done both now. I guess my question is...is there hope? Is there hope the man I love will come bac
k out of this and still love me? Even though he says he doesn't have feelings now from the depression and only says ""I don't know"", I know how he felt before this, I know the depression makes everything harder and pushes away your loved ones, and makes it so you can't form rational or healthy thoughts...but depression changes people...will it change his feelings for me? 175993796,"I’m bipolar. Honestly it’s really hard to get started on the medication when you’re strung out and manic. He may be addicted to his meds but if he doesn’t take that one med, he would probably be even more manic so I’d try to regulate his intake if anything. Getting started is the hardest part of it. Once you’re a month in it’s gets so much easier but it’s rough and hard to reason at the beginning. What’s important is that he has tour support even though he’s manic. That always made a huge difference to me kinda knowing that someone was there for me and genuinely wanted to support me no matter how bad it got. Destroying everything in his path is self destruction, I used to do it too. Things got REALLY bad for me before I got any better. Hang in there, if you have a therapist go to more therapy so you can relieve some tension and I would work out if you have the time, it helps a lot. Hang in there! When he does come back he’ll be super thankful to you and it will make the bigges
t difference even though it’s really really hard to stick around."

174393660,"Hi, I was very touched and concerned when I read your post. I have schizophrenia and know how hard that can be on loved ones, as well as the person affected with it. My mom has been a rock for me. I don't know what I would do without her support. As I am, your son is very blessed to have a caring and supportive mom. I know not everyone is as supportive, my ex-husband of 20 years left me before I even fully recovered from an episode. I was devastated and felt so alone. But it made me appreciate even more the support I had, especially from my mom and also my brother. I know the episodes are extremely scary and so hard to go through for the person and their love ones. However, I wanted you to know after some tries, I found a medication that for now anyway, seems to be working for me. I haven't had an episode in a year and a half. So there can be light at the end of the tunnel. As for making your son take his meds, I know that is very difficult. I know for me, when I have gone through episodes, I also 
saw things and heard voices that seemed so real to me. I was 100 percent convinced they were real, and I was terrified people were out to harm me. I insisted on getting a security camera, trying to record voices that weren't real, not being alone, extra. My love ones told me that I could do these things and they would consider the option that what I was experiencing was real, but that they wanted me to also promise to try taking meds. So I did, even though I didn't think I needed them. The meds saved my life. I don't know if this will work for your son, but it did for me. Besides that, being loving, supportive and trying to get him to a psychologist and a counselor might help. I was committed once against my will and I know from personal experience that I hated it and just wanted out. I am sure it is helpful for some people, but I never want to end up there again. I don't know if this will help or work but I wanted to share my own experience with you. I just looked back at your post and it is from a while ago
, I didn't notice that at first. If you are still reading these posts, I wish the best for you and your son. I hope you were able to get help for him."

175993886,"lie down, close your eyes, start with the top of your head and imagine that the suns rays are gently warming your scalp. then the rays are moving on down and gently warming your forehead. And as you feel the suns rays gently warming your forehead a sense of calm is coming over you. and then you feel it on your face and on down to each part of your body slowly. At each step of the way your taking the time to really concentrate on how good it feels and how relaxed you are. Do this until you get to the bottom of your feet. You will be very relaxed, calm and grounded."

175993893,"If you mean you doubt they could see through your eyes -- realize there are (from memory, on The Doctors TV Show) things which for ""blind"" people can take a camera image and sort of send it on an optic cell -- And please research The Brain Initiative from sites like ieee (they have free non-commercial information). You can find videos which discuss stuff like ""Stimdust"" which they will tell you are ""out there, in the wild"" -- which is a fancy way of saying they exist and you can find public information about them. The concept of stimdust was they were tiny electronic ""nerve receptor"" cuffs which can hook on the neurons and both 'read' when a nerve is firing and transmit to an external ""transceiver"" (transmitter/receiver) and also receive signals from a transceiver and enact a nerve firing, so they can read and write your brain. _USER_ID_ : I said stim dust, the ""education page"" on ieee referred to it as ""Neural Dust"" but it's the same idea _USER_ID_ 2: I saw somewhere that this neural 
dust could be created with a laser from a $15 ""lightscribe"" dvd burner, meaning it could possibly be created by someone without many resources, but i don't really know all that's involved. In theory, it could be created by something like a ""computer virus"" with access to your DVD burner (details again are not clear)."

175993898,"I relate. Its not just with people that I find it difficult to muster interest /energy but with most things in life. Few things motivate me emotionally or physically. I look back on activities I used to find the energy to engage in and am amazed that I was ever like that. I cannot imagine the kind of conversations I must have had, or the motivation, to have sought certain adventures over the years. I could say I have become anhedonic except I do appreciate a great t.v. series and recently was motivated, emotionally, to rescue a small dog running helter skelter on a dangerous road. I was motivated enough to risk causing an accident by stopping on a dangerous bend and cause traffic to stop as I ran after him, and managed to get him in my car. I am stuck with him now, and cannot put in much energy to find his owner. But I am getting a kick out of understanding his nature. There is a battle of wits going on that is much more appealing than any human engagement. Its weird how every time I give up on lif
e a stray animal comes my way and it eeks out a little something I still have left to give. Energy IS the key word. Therefore I think it is useful to think about what does energise or motivate one, if anything, rather than dwell on why one cannot find the energy to engage in what most others can do effortlessly. Perhaps other people are less sincere and it takes less out of them to relate in a superficial way to others for the sake of business, work, socially etc.. Perhaps the schizoid is not motivated enough by self interest... who knows. Another thing I find is when I am angry I have plenty of energy with which to engage with others. I find it an easier energy to expend than superficial politeness."

175993958,"It's hard to manage depression and anxiety in a non-supportive environment. I don't know what it's like to be in the military. I can imagine, on the one hand, the benefits of its camaraderie and, on the other hand, the conformity and difficulty of sharing vulnerability. It would seem to me that, until you feel stronger, you should put your game face on and retreat a bit into yourself. The key here is ""until you feel stronger."" How do you do that? Reading CBT self-help books, finding an online support group (go to _USER_ID_ to find one), keep chatting here and, most importantly, seek out therapy and medication for depression. But remove yourself from bad situations. If there's stuff going on that is not good for you and you can, walk away. Listen to music or an audiobook, write a journal, take cell phone pictures... anything until you are calm. Then day by day, rebuild your sense of self worth, with professional support. Step by step. Persevere. Take care."

175994074,"I'm not sure why your doctors won't let you retest or what state you're in that they won't let you retest. There should be a place in your state that you can simply drive into for a retest. I had two nasal swab tests which came back negative even though I STILL had symptoms over a month later. Based on the fact I still had symptoms, I was able to go to my doctor and get a script for the IGG-IGm test (vial antibody as opposed to the pin prick one they do for antibodies). Is it the doctor giving you a hard time or the insurance company? If it's the insurance company, call them up directly and let them know you require a test to ensure you're not spreading it everywhere since you both still have symptoms. You can also tell them you want to give blood, but they won't allow you to until you can prove you're no longer contagious any more. The blood bank will want your antibodies to treat someone else."

175994101,"Under treatment resistant panic disorder, one website said try the ssri’s etc, that you’ve tried, but start off at ½ regular dosage, and give it longer time to take effect. Another website (Psychiatrictimes.com., Treatment-Resistant Panic Disorder, November 27, 2017), said: “Switch to another antidepressant agent. Within-class switching may not be a high-yield intervention. However, switching to an agent with a different pharmacodynamic profile is a reasonable step. For example, one good option is imipramine, often overlooked because of its risk of cardiotoxicity in overdose; yet it is one of the most intensively studied antipanic agents available. MAOIs, also seldom used now, can be surprisingly helpful as well.” And, “Consider benzodiazepine monotherapy. While clinical guidelines tend to rank benzodiazepines as second- or third-line antipanic agents, this is primarily because of concerns about sedation, physiological dependence, psychological dependence, and the slight risk of benzodia
zepine abuse/diversion, especially with longer-term use. In fact, benzodiazepines are similarly effective to antidepressants for panic disorder, and their panicolytic benefit is almost always sustained over the long term."" So, we're back to where we were, and where you are now: benzos. I take one, Ativan, for a physical condition. I'd rather not, but It keeps me functioning."

175994139,"It’s good that you wrote in. You said, “My wife has always exhibited mild symptoms of bipolar disorder, but was never diagnosed, or even really thought about it.” As far as diagnosed, it sounds like she is bipolar, as I am. Mayoclinic.org says the symptoms of depression are: ""feel(ing) sad or hopeless and lose interest or pleasure in most activities."" ""When your mood shifts to mania or hypomania (less extreme than mania), you may feel euphoric, full of energy or unusually irritable. These mood swings can affect sleep, energy, activity, judgment, behavior and the ability to think clearly."" I inherited my bipolar from my mother’s mother. The way I came to find out my diagnosis was by talking to a lay counselor who knew my uncle and he said, “He was bipolar, and you probably are, too.” The psychiatrists I had seen missed it, since I had come in as depressed and they diagnosed me as depressed. Why they couldn’t ask me questions about possible mania, I don’t know. But when they dx yo
u wrong, they medicate you wrong. They can dx you as only depressed, give you anti-depressants, which can send you into mania. But with nothing to treat the mania (I take Lithium stabilizer for that and Mirtazapine anti-depressant), I had anxiety attacks. So it’s very important that the psy. knows about the mania if your wife goes in as depressed. Bipolar can start in teens or early 20s, net says. It can be very difficult to get a bipolar to see a psy. When I was manic, I couldn’t slow down enough to even think about that or what to do if I did think about it. When depressed, I didn’t feel like going to a psy. When did I go? When I was depressed. Why? Probably because my mother talked me into it. What would that be, intervention? Can you talk to her when she's depressed about this? It usually takes a family member, and you qualify. She won't trust an outsider. I would think you would also need the name of a psy. You can look up on the net search engine for: “psychiatrist for my hometown.” Write down 
a few names and phone numbers and pick one. You might want to call one or more local hospitals and ask them if they have a women’s health center. Ask them if they can recommend the name of a psychiatrist, and a therapist while you’re talking to them. Then see if she’ll go in just for a therapy session, then ask the therapist for the name of a psychiatrist. There are all kinds of medicines for this. My grandmother had bipolar but there were no medicines for that in the 1930's, 40's and early 1950's. So she lived some years in a state mental institution, 100 miles from home. So your wife is actually in a good situation, she just doesn’t know it. My grandmother would have given anything for medicine. She used to go into people’s medicine cabinets looking for a pill that would make her better. Your wife has the medicines available to her but won’t go to a psy. to get them. Several types of treatment are available and one of them is called cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) which this website, healingw
ell,com, advocates. Data for that on this forum (bipolar) can be found above the list of names of people, such as you, who have written in for suggestions. You might want to look at that. CBT is described as, “identifying unhealthy, negative beliefs and behaviors and replacing them with healthy, positive ones. CBT can help identify what triggers your bipolar episodes. You also learn effective strategies to manage stress and to cope with upsetting situations."" It’s a matter of trying to be positive about the problem, any problem, before you go into it so it can increase your chances of solving it by having a mindset that looks for a solution (positive) rather than a defeat (negative). Any negative will be in the unconscious so you won’t see it, which is why it is important that you believe going into the problem that you can solve it (positive thinking). If you go into the problem thinking, this is over my head, then it closes down your unconscious to deliberately not find a solution, cause your conscio
us told it to. But if you go into the same problem thinking you can solve it, it opens up your unconscious to look for a solution. Because you told it to. Your unconscious is waiting for orders."

175994183,"I think it's more complicated than that. For myself, being alone is more of a need than a preference. When I'm with others, I feel disjointed, like I'm unraveling. It's hard to concentrate, much like trying to remember a number while some smartass shouts out random digits at you to make you forget. I can't focus. My mind feels sloppy. I'm not the most cognizant person in the world, but being around other people makes it worse. Getting away means I can regain my composure, feel more like me again, and be able to think. I think this helps create the illusion that being alone is more comfortable. Another reason is that I find most people boring, or at least not interesting or relatable enough to hold my attention, but I'm not sure if this isn't just a symptom of the discomfort they cause just by being in proximity."

175994197,"The gum works really well but I like the nicotine spray better because I can get 4mg straight to my brains. I buy the 4mg nicotine gum instead of the 2mg. Remember, once you feel satisfied, there's no need to chew another gum for at least 45 minutes to 4 hours because you don't get high from nicotine.. it's just from the withdrawal of the previous hit of nicotine. It takes 3 days for the nicotine to completely leave the system and then 7 days for the tolerance to go away. Then you feel like you're on nicotine all the time. I just haven't quit the nicotine because I don't feel like going through that process of withdrawing because I love nicotine but I will soon. Then I won't be using nicotine at all. I'm definitely NEVER smoking cigarettes again."

175994201,"I have done EMDR with 2 different therapists. It didn't work for me for quite some time, but about 2 months ago I did a session focusing on something that got me quite emotional (regarding expectations of me as a child that were beyond my age), I cried, which I normally don't do in therapy sessions. That night I had dreams of removing myself from harmful situations from my past. It was actually really great. I've noticed an improvement around some things that I am usually very anxious about . I'm certainly not ""cured"" of anxiety, but I feel I had a good breakthrough in that particular session. I will say that in some EMDR sessions, I became more upset afterwards and in others, I didn't feel anything either way. I think the effectiveness of EMDR really depends on the practitioner and the memory you choose to focus/work on."

I had a follow up Zoom call with the doctor and she was completely un-phased by it and does not want to retest at all because everything else was within normal limits. The acute stress and panic from it has also made me lose my appetite and increased my IBS-D which is annoying ?. But I also have no one else to blame but myself because I’m eating my trigger foods. The funny thing is about my trigger foods is they sometimes irritate my stomach, and sometimes are fine so it’s hard to keep up. I’m exhausted from being so scared all the time."

Here's the journal: Welcome to my little story that will shock you to know is 100% true. on all this. The leader who lives at the above address is a older gentleman of 52 years old who goes by the call sign ""Mr _PERSON_!"" The very first of it I don't have complete memory of so the exact start time is left to a journal I wrote at the time. Little did I know much more would be happening over the following months. ? Along with the use of these emitters was the use of hypnosis. They had me believing some pretty crazy crap. First was the bulge in my stomach. . But he told me because of the bulge in my stomach rupturing he would have to nuke _PERSON_ to cover up the talking to me as well as the bulge situation. My past was brought back and my home and pets were gone. I told the psychiatrist straight up that when I got out I was going to kill myself. He didn’t believe me. 3 days later I was released to go home. I knew exactly what I was going to do. I got my medications picked up and headed for motel 6 with one goal in mind, to die. I only got a weeks supply of my meds so it wasn’t the amount I was aiming for. Soon the sun was setting. It was time. The same lighting condition of the solitary room when I was 16 that I was locked in. I took the Lithium and Celexa. I passed out about a half hour later. This was it, no one to come and walk in on me. But once again I woke up. As some might know who takes it, Lithium is a salt. I got the runs very badly. One time not making it and filling my pants. Gross I know. But it happened. Mr _PERSON_ stil
l had his hooks in me. Shocks came when trying to sleep without permission. Making comments about my condition and such. I was just sick with severe diarrhea. Well, that’s not a fool proof way to die is it. Check, don’t do that again. Two days later and 4 Gatorade’s later my mom shows up about my car. It’s costing too much to keep the car in storage. It needs 1700 dollars worth of work before I can get it smogged. So we took it to pick and pull and only got 50 bucks from it. Well 47 because of some “trash” left in it. It hurt. I just couldn’t afford to keep it in storage anymore. Another day at the motel and then I was on the streets. My mom helped me run some errands giving me a ride to the stores to get what I needed. I have a backpack with two changes of clothes, Puppy my stuffed puppy dog and a few odds and e
nds. She finally dropped me off at the local library so I could use their wifi till dinner. I made it 10 minutes before I left the library. I walked around the block not knowing where to go or what to do with myself. I decided forget it, I was going to confront Mr _PERSON_, Mr _NAME_ and Miss _NAME_ once and for all. I set out on my way walking toward my mom’s house since Mr _PERSON_ lived next door. I knew I wasn’t supposed to go there, but I didn’t care. The walk of over 20 blocks about killed me. My heart pounding as I walked. I finally made it a block away from Mr _PERSON_’s house when my mom called to ask how I was. I was honest and said I was looking at the building’s laundry room and was going to confront Mr _PERSON_. Next thing I see is her walking out to the car and picks me up about 300 feet from Mr _PERSON_’s door. Of course she was angry. She was mad I walked there and put her housing at risk. rove me to Mercy Medical Center where I was checked in for a mental health hold as I was once again suicidal. Two days later I get a surprise visit. Seems due to the whole mental health crisis with Mr _PERSON_ and his group and the suicide attempts they want to see if I qualify to be conserved making someone else in charge of all my decisions. At the end of the talk I get handed a temporary court order of conservation while the court decides. That all happened at the end of February 2020. I spent another 17 days in the ER waiting for placement. All the hospitals that had openings were for danger to self or other. Since I was only gravely disabled due to not being able to find housing I just sat in the ER. Finally I get a visit from the directory of the CRRC (Crisis Residential and Recovery Center). which is in charge of my case. The up side is I got my own room instead of being in the rooms with 3 other guys. It helps since I am a shy person and isolate a lot. 175994230,"So you got your anxiety from your father. That’s good to know. I got my bipolar from my mother’s mother and it took about 10 years before psychiatrists diagnosed me right. Because I told them. The only way I found out was, I was talking on the phone to a lay counselor about my difficulties and he said, “I knew your uncle. He was manic-depressive and you probably are too.” I was very grateful to find out so I could be medicated right. As for positive attitude, I stumbled upon that also. It was in a newspaper column in which the woman said if you go into a problem thinking you can solve it, it really increases your chances that you will. For I think it opens up your unconscious to look for ways to solve the issue, for you just told it to. Otherwise, since we can’t see our unconscious, it could be set on negative, from childhood for instance, when we believed what we were told: you’re worthless, you can’t solve problems. So now before I go into a problem, I say, “Think positive, think 
positive, think positive,” to make sure my unconscious is set on positive--like I told it to--not on negative like somebody else may have told it to when I was 5 or 10. Or, one problem at a time, and be positive about that problem. Somebody else told me this--the woman who wrote the column--and it worked, that’s why I’m telling you."

174394168,"It can be hard to deal with psychosis. My episodes were usually mania with acute paranoia and psychotic episodes that were pretty intense. 175994274,"Hi _NAME_ and welcome! I am glad that you are looking to get more comfortable with your treatment regimen. I think we know intuitively what we need to do in order to feel our best, and if you believe that your time with using a benzo has run its course, then you are right to look on ahead to other options. You will want to, as _PERSON_ mentioned, taper your discontinuation with your Klonopin. You can go to .25 and .5 for a week, and then to just your most needed dose for another week, (just the a.m. pill OR the p.m. instead of both) and then finally that same dose but only on every other day until you step off after the 3rd or 4th week. That should be a good schedule considering your low total dosage and the short amount of time you have been taking them...but consulting your doctor or pharmacist is always a good move if you aren't sure about it all. As far as the Valerian and Gaba...natural supplements can be beneficial, but don't work for everyone. (if this was the case we wouldn't have need for 
pharmaceuticals) So try it and stay positive about it working for you, but having a back up plan is also a good idea. Vistaril (hydroxyzine) a prescript ion antihistamine taken off label for anxiety/panic is something you might want to research and keep in consideration as a benzo alternative...just in case. Also seek to learn new coping skills that you can add to your toolbelt to help you get through your transition. If you need new material, we have great ideas in our Resources at the top of the main forum page here. Keep posting with us as well for support if you find it helpful. We care, understand and support is key! Talk soon and well wishes with your discontinuation! S.C."

175994299,"Hi _NAME_, Have you tried ashwaganda?I used to have terrible chronic insomnia. It'll literally make someone nuts... Sometimes, I go to bed early & just lay there reading after taking the herbal remedies and that helps. Hope you start sleeping well soon."

175994319,"It's not always a permanent solution to a temporary problem. Sometimes it's a permanent solution to many permanent problems!!! But regardless, not all problems are temporary, so that is a false statement. When It is at the point that they no longer care how negative they sound or no longer care if people think less of them, that's pretty rock bottom. Me, personally, I want to hear I am weak so bad!! How could bpd patients not hate being told they are strong?? It is mostly just a persons way to protect themselves in case that unfortunate bpd person they perceived as strong, fails. They can say ""but he/she seemed so strong!! If a person suffers an incredible amount of loss and trauma and is still breathing, how does that make them strong??!!! It's a strength if they are able to overcome all that loss and trauma!! We would gladly admit we are weak if they would just keep most of that pain away from us!! Or let us have the help we should get. Not just a few that find that rare therapist who agrees to 
help one or two bpd patients. How hard it is to feel Hopeless. And Helpless. that is what the therapist should have just said when they inform us that they are unable to treat us. How can they turned us away!! Over and over if there was any hope of getting better? I got turned down everytime i asked and even pleaded for help. Most of us have tolerated much more than we are capable of dealing with when therapist after therapist abandons and rejects us over and over!!! Really? It's abusing us using our biggest fear!! ! And having a Grief Center rejecting us too? Even when they know we have multiple losses and traumas we are trying to find help to make some sense out of? And to find out we are being abandoned yet again? But this time it was a person who supposedly dedicated their lives to help, not injure. And Why even tell us we have multiple cases of complicated grief, and all the painful feelings too, when the next therapist is coming to tell us she can't treat us either.. she leaves us all alone, once again, 
with all that pain,.. and no hope that anyone will even bother to throw us a rope. Just like a therapist who does decide to treat a bpd patient, is required to see a therapist,also. Just think how lonely and raw and empty the borderline is feeling because they see the trouble they cause. Having bpd is feeling like our body is 90% covered w 3rd degree burns!! How painful and paralyzingly those feelings must be!! And for the most part, always will be. Our feelings are all over the place, and if one negative feeling is too intense, it could take an hour to calm down even just a little!! Not even to count the other difficult psych diagnosis' that are usually always present with bpd like ptsd and GAD and severe MDD!! Then add physical problems on top of all of those raw and painful feelings! No wonder they view death as being better. Bpd is considered the most painful psychiatric disorder. The pain would be too unbearable for the strongest of people without bpd!! And most of u can only slightly imagine how painful 
just living is for the bpd person:(((("

then to my community....and I keep expanding it. It feels good for a bit, to not be so self immersed. And seems like it’s my job now. Staying quiet, meditative, and sending love. 174394281,"The problem is that those constructs are medical ones, at least in psychiatry. They mean something, and there is a protocol to follow in order to diagnose. If people don't, it is just using terms badly in order to suggest other things, or using credentials that you don't have. If you say callousness is enough, the problem is that there are plenty of callous people, and they don't do anything antisocial. Let's just take conduct disorder, which is pretty much the same construct as antisocial PD. It is necessary that there is a pattern of disruptive behaviors. https://ijponline.biomedcentral.com/art ... 017-0404-6 The socialization of those with this behavior is all over the place, and so is the emotions, callous or not. That's why, something specific like serial murders, simply does not fit the pattern in and of itself, no matter how horrific you might want to call it, it is not antisocial in a scientific way, but only in a vague colloquial way. Its also not something the person can ""hide"", nor are 
any of the other personality disorders, otherwise, what's the point of it? it can't be seen, and therefore cannot be diagnosed either. If people start doing that, it is simply guess work. Medical conditions can be seen, they are not something you just make up without any symptoms. And that is the problem here. If you assume there are covert antisocials, and covert psychopaths that are undetectable, and commit serial murders and can only be diagnosed once caught, it is a serious problem, and can explain everything, just like the unconscious. Its basically pseudo-science. But it is true that many people that commit those typed of crimes do have that observable behavior. I don't believe it is the reason they do it though, but it is a risk factor. Those are easier to catch, since they probably have priors with the law. The problem here is that Stone makes a lot of emphasis on the callous-unemotional factor, and it seems like it is his goal to make it more evil, and he wants to have harsher sentences for people th
at have the wrong emotions. There is a problem here though, since it is hard to tell from afar, the actual psychic process. ""The psychic process dynamics, despite being extremely important, can confuse the professional in the categorization of PDs. For example, a psychiatrist can confuse the affective state of schizophrenia, or even that of schizoidism (which is characterized by a deficient affective expression), with the indifference and affective insensitivity of antisocial PD."" http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=s15 ... xt&tlng=en Here's another time the myths. https://www.scientificamerican.com/arti ... t-excerpt/ The majority of them are not loners, and they fit quite well into the community. The majority means the majority, which means more than 47%. According to Stone, the vast majority are psychopaths, and sexual sadists, and half are schizoids. Somehow, he is not seeing the same thing as everybody else. His only study seems to be this: https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2001-_PHONE_NO_ I could not fin
d the whole text, but he is basing his opinions mainly on biographies. That's quite a problem, and I would take that with a grain of salt. From a strictly scientific point of view, it is quite useless. If he actually took their real official diagnosis, it would be more useful, but he makes his own, based on very limited data, web searches, and media coverage (yes, I checked a few things about his method). Just in normal sexual homicide cases, the PDs that are diagnosed, when there is one are ASPD, BPD and NPD in order, from what I saw, which makes a lot more sense. If you include murder in general, not the sexual type, PPD is often second. I don't know why he decided to diagnose all those people with SPD, but my guess is their lack of emotional display, and some of them are somewhat loners. Its not exactly enough for a diagnosis, but if you stretch everything's possible. When you simply look at third hand accounts of the media or Hollywood, many people look like loners, which may or may not be consistent with 
the reality. That's why interviews are generally considered necessary, it's the _PERSON_ rule, and Stone broke it. He was properly diagnosed at least, and yes, both can be true at the same time, but he wasn't diagnosed as SPD as far as I saw. BPD and some ASPD traits. Its not what wikipedia believes, its what he was diagnosed with in reality, and not from a search engine. [quote=""number230000""] It's related to Borderline Personality Organization in general - therefore schizoid - of which polymorphous perverse sexuality is a symptom.[quote] Schizoids don't have a borderline personality organization, but that is psychoanalysis, different beast."

175994417,"medved said... _AT_MENTION_ - Ativan can be pretty addictive. Same with other benzodiazepines. I save that for once in a blue moon use. If your wife is motivated to beat the health anxiety, that might be the best approach. I really don't think my wife will opt for any meds again. I felt much more like my old self again. My sex drive actually had increased, my appetite returned, food tasted good, and diarrhea was calming down. Day 4: I felt a bit less nauseated, but still shaky, sweaty, and super spacy. Upon waking I noticed that my jaw has a small tremor. By the evening my anxiety was back. Day 5 (Today): I woke to

175994432,"Minipuff: It does sound good. You are where my grandmother as a bipolar wanted to be, except there wasn’t any medicine. Again, we can be thankful that we were born into an era when there is medicine, and many of them. She was of the era of the 1920s, and a couple of decades after, when there were basically no medicines for those types of illnesses. Here in 2020, it is 100 years later than that. This is what she was wishing for. And we've done absolutely nothing to deserve it. Instead of medicine, she was housed in a central state mental hospital with high walls. During those years, she didn’t live at home, like we are, but in a big, cold building with high walls. As I’ve mentioned before, when my grandmother was visiting someone, she would go into their medicine cabinets and take some of the pills, probably thinking, “Pills make people well, why won’t these make me well?” Again, you’re living her dream. You never spent a day in a hospital. You could be still feeling like you were when 
you first posted. That’s a miracle. Again, we should be down on our knees in thanks for modern medicine. You say, “Surprisingly, no notable anxiety.” That’s a lot different than your fist post. Then you talk about the elevator. So, you did manage to step in and off of one? That’s very good. As for Melatonin, in addition to regular medicine, you might start off with one or two 1 mg.’s. I would see how that worked, and then the next night adjust it to what you think. One trick is to take it, say, an hour early to give it time to start working. Another trick is to take one just before you go to bed, or an hour later than the first pill or pills, so it will be like time release. They might even sell time release, I don’t know. Also, if I keep waking up at say 3 a.m. and can’t get back to sleep, I’ll consider taking another one. Of course, if you’re going to have to be up by a certain time, that might not be best. Again, these are some of the standards for me and alternatives, but I would start 
off with say 1 or 2 and see how it goes. You’ll have to decide those things. Oh, yeah, I was going to ask you about your being positive. Is that going OK? The medicine helps, but our attitude does, also. Mine changed when I read a column on being positive. I didn’t know it, but I had been unconsciously negative. That woman changed my attitude in 10 paragraphs, with perhaps the main one being, “Going into a problem thinking you can solve it, doubles your chances that you will.” I found that it does, as it flips your unconscious from negative to positive, and puts your unconscious to work solving the problem, rather than tripping you up, if you've ordered it to be negative. Before, my unconscious had been set on negative, as I had been raised. Now I think before going into a problem, “Think positive, think positive, think positive.” How have you been at solving problems, lately? “One problem at a time and be positive about that problem.”"

175994462,"The thing is, to explain something to someone, you first have to determine a point of commonality, and then kind of walk them step by step to where your head is. So, sometimes I look at a person, and I look at my position, and I look off into the distance at the point of commonality, and it's just an exhaustive mental distance away. But that's just a function of a large amount of time in solitary, away from people. People have these core values of these relationships. Like, people plan to go on vacations with family, and celebrate milestones, and go places to take photos of themselves in front of places, and make all of these nostalgic self-associations with music, and media, and gossip. So much of normal human existance is really relationship-based, so if you divorce yourself from that idea, you get very, very weird in a very, very short period of time."

175994501,"I think it does have something to do with it, Oblivion. I like the phrase ""anticipatory dread""; it's on point. It's a way to push back feelings though. Put distance between yourself and emotion. A wall up, as you say. Living at a distance from your body/your emotional-physiological response. Instead of feeling it in the instant (when you're more vulnerable and prone to feel out of control), you think it / feel it before it happens as a way to process it and then compartmentalize it. Then, when it occurs, you aren't as fearful of what your emotions might do to you. It's a form of intellectualization. My husband's a master at it. He's just now recognizing it for what it is, and starting to work on it - at least sufficiently so that he increases his capacity to feel his feelings contemporaneous to the event more."
175994502,"Good to hear that you were calm. Again, while you are being positive and appreciating things, which I think is very good, I hope you remember the state you were in (sobbing and crying and panic attacks) when you first posted 3 months ago. With the added medicine being the difference. You should also be glad you have a good psychiatrist. And also that you are being treated at home instead of a state mental institution 100 miles from your home, with basically no medicine at that institution. Again, you were lucky to be born in an era when they have effective medicines for emotional problems. You said the sound of someone eating, was not from your being bothered by that, but from your father being bothered by that, and at his outbursts if someone ate too loudly. For you said: “And when it comes to the noise thing, I can pinpoint down to specific situations as a child, that has caused me to react this way. I can't stand repetitive sounds, and when I was a child, if I sang a song more than once or ban
ged on a drum or anything that was repetitive, my father would SCREAM at me. The same thing w the eating, I can actually remember having a really bad head cold and having problems swallowing my dinner. You know when your stuffed up and have to kind of gulp air and really choke food down? I was doing that, and my father screamed at me to stop. At the next bite of food, I did it again and he got so angry he told me he wouldn't let me eat if I couldn't eat properly. Those types of moments were frequent growing up. And I think subconsciously, I am so worried about upsetting someone with those types of sounds that I don't want anyone to do that.” When I typed in something like “repetitive sounds” into the search engine, WebMd.com said, “People with a disorder called misophonia have an intense hatred of specific sounds, such as chewing, breathing or repeated pen clicking. These triggers can cause an immediate and strong ""fight or flight"" response in those with the disorder.” Due to, “an abnormality in 
their emotional control mechanism that puts their brains into overdrive when they hear trigger sounds.” When you hear repetitive sounds, it doesn’t bother you, but it bothered your father who would lash out verbally, and now you are so worried about bothering your father, who doesn’t live with you, that everybody has to eat quietly. And you add: “But boy that's a hard thing to break. I'm not making excuses for my behavior, I realize, after, that quite often my reaction is irrational or excessive. I understand that. I'm trying.” How do you eat at the same table? Do we need to get back to being positive when trying to solve a problem? Do you remember any of that? Also, I think, you and your husband should work out a system in which you do not have to scream to get your point across after you’ve made your first request. You do not have to be degraded to that point, nor he. Also, your child does not have to hear that. That’s noise to his ears which you two aren’t being respective of. First, he sho
uld not eat around you if that causes such a reaction. Second, if you ask him to stop, he should stop. Third, if you leave the room he should not follow you. Fourth, you should not scream around your child. You should work out a system in advance of how to handle this. My thoughts are, you’re not Borderline Personality Disorder. You had no trauma in childhood. 1234"

175994577,"I also struggle with OCD. I remember doing things as a child that only now do I realize were symptoms of OCD such as checking the door to make sure it was locked over and over again. My OCD was moderate until I graduated from high school and ever since then it has been ""flaring up"" and then fading only to have a new obsessions then ""flare up."" I recently started seeing a therapist after my OCD became debilitating and my symptoms have improved sooo much. The main treatment for OCD is ERP therapy which you can always try doing on your own first and then seeing a therapist if you feel like you need one. In my experience, most therapists aren't trained in ERP so I am seeing an OCD specialist. Here is an article explaining ERP: https://iocdf.org/expert-opinions/expert-opinion-self-directed-erp/"

174394745,"_AT_MENTION_, My side effects seem to come about two months into the medication and they don't go away. Most people get side effects in the beginning and they subside in about 10 days. Unfortunately mine don't go that way. Buspar-didn't work Paxil-sexual side effects Zoloft-diarrhea Prozac-weight gain Lexapro-sexual side effects and weight gain Wellbutrin-agitation I can't tolerate the SSRI's at all. But tried SNRI and it worked well. I may have gained a little weight but I take so much medications that I am not sure what caused it. I take Pristiq, xanax and abilify. I think an increase of the abilify caused a little weight gain. But when the side effects didn't go away I just switched medications. I have been taking xanax for about 30 years and didn't have any side effects. I have been taking pristiq for 10 years. I switched from effexor when it went generic (which I took for about 15 years). Pristiq is generic now too but I take a kind that seems exactly like the brand name. It looks like it too 
and I think some of it is psychological because it looks like the brand name to me. I tried one that looked different and after two months I was depressed again. So some of it could be in my head, but as long as it works. Luckily I am retired. But it was hard switching medications and dealing with side effects while working. You never know what to expect. 175994686,So I am 23 years young. But I feel like time is just flying by me. I am in a very happy relationship and have no kids(yet.) I live a happy life. But I get thoughts/episodes all the time and I freak out and start crying for no reason and I can’t stop these thoughts. Let me explain a little bit. So tonight I had an “episode” (as I call it.) I have them all time but this is the first one in a couple of weeks. So I’m laying in bed trying to get to sleep and all of the sudden I start thinking about my life and how I feel as if I’m not doing enough. I mean I have a steady full time job that I love. I do volunteer work. And I help people whenever they need it. I have a very happy relationship and wouldn’t change a thing about my life. But I feel like I’m not doing anything useful with my life and time is just passing me by and I’m not living my life to the fullest. Which brings me to my “episode.” As I’m thinking about time passing me by I start thinking about how I’m getting older 
and not having any kids yet. —I know I’m young. Everyone tells me that it’s okay to wait to have kids. And I understand that and I’m okay with it but when I have episodes it makes me feel as if I need to start having kids now or it’s to late. I feel as if I wait to have kids I’m going to be to old And not be able to see them graduate or get married and have kids if they choose etc. I don’t wanna be the “old” mom I guess kinda thought. I don’t know. But as I’m thinking about that I start to think about my S/O and I growing old and thinking about if he passes before me I’m going to be alone and have no one and vice versa. I just start thinking about how if that were to happen that I wouldn’t have him to talk to anymore or have anyone to do anything with or share jokes with and being alone in our home. Sure we might have kids/grandkids then but they wouldn’t have the bond/understand the feeling of sharing those things with my S/O. I get that kids and grandkids can stay with or visit b
ut it’s not the same. I get thoughts like this all the time because I just start to imagine us old and then being alone. And I start thinking about my sisters and how they are gonna pass before me and how alone I’ll feel without them. And how her kids are gonna take it. And I start thinking about my S/Os family the same. And I just start crying. And I can’t stop. When I have these thoughts it makes me feel as if time is slipping away and passing by and I’m losing my life minute by minute and soon it’ll be over. So I’m laying here tonight crying and thinking these thoughts and I don’t want too. I have no one to talk to about this and I feel as if no one will understand. I feel like I’m the only one to do this. Everyone tells me all the time that I’m “23 years young and I still have about 60 years to go” but I feel like that “60 years.” Is going by way to fast. It last for upwards to an hour or two. I have to calm myself down by saying you shouldn’t be having these thoughts and think
ing about what I have now and goals that are set. And then kinda forcing myself to go to bed just to forget about it. I guess I’m terrified of growing older. I’m terrified of having the people I love around me passing away and me being stuck all alone. I’m terrified of passing away. I don’t know. I don’t know what to do anymore. And I just need to vent about it cause it’s getting to hard to hold in and too hard to not have anyone to talk to. I don’t have anyone really except my S/O And my sisters and we’re not that close. I don’t really have friends and I’m scared that I’m always gonna be alone. I don’t know....... that’s all for tonight I guess I can’t type anymore through the tears and tryin got calm my self down.

174394772,"Wikipedia: (not empirical I know, but if you web search the terms, lots of proper research papers come up on it) Yet, while drugs like speed and coke are more likely to cause psychosis as opposed to something like pot, pot is the drug most likely to genetically trigger (those predisposed to it) an ongoing/permanent psychotic disorder. ^ That's a big difference and is counterintuitive to the theory. Your experience also hits upon points that poke holes in dopamine hypothesis. I've already said earlier in the thread I don't like it. Sensory gating atypicalities yes, but not dopamine hypothesis Also, close to every antipsychotic is a dopamine antagonist, yet anywhere you look, it seems like the numbers are way too low to be as dopamine related as they claim (and it's not considering the people who have developed ways of functioning with psychotic symptoms, but keep it to themselves due to _USER_ID_, etc): https://www.nationalelfservice.net/trea ... coreboard/ I read 1/3 as effectiveness elsewhere. I'd 
say I'm a decent example of that. The ones I remember being on: seroquel, zyprexia, risperidone, chlorpromazine, nozinan, zeldox, abilify, loxapine, haldol Psychiatrists have noted that, with me, the drugs don't particularly do anything - other than lobotomize me chemically. Psychosis is a coping mechanism and response to life for me at times. I acknowledge that antipsychotics can be vital to the treatment for some people and it can be downright dangerous to stop them without medical supervision"

174394865,"There are certainly certain mental illnesses that require medication. For example, schizophrenia. And some patients with anxiety disorders and/or depression will benefit from medication. But other patients will do just as well or better with (only) CBT or other psychotherapy, without having to endure the side effects of medication. And the benefits of psychotherapy may be more enduring than the benefits of medication. There have been a bunch of studies that address this issue. Here’s one, just as an example: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/pmc2748674/ Post Edited By Moderator (getting by) : 10/20/2019 1:48:42 PM (GMT-6)"

175994824,"https://file.scirp.org/pdf/JCC_2_PHONE_NO_.pdf Over the past years a booming interest is comprehended in the field of wireless communication for the development of a monitoring system to observe human vital organs activities remotely. Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) is such network that provides a continuous monitoring over or inside human body for a long period and can support transmission of real time traffic such as data, voice, video to observe the status of vital organs functionalities. In this paper an overview of WBAN technology and its requirements has been narrated. The aim of this paper was to offer a suitable and appropriate wireless technology for deploying WBAN. Several suitable short range wireless communication technologies that can be adopted in WBAN have also been discussed. Finally numerous applications in the field of medical and non-medical sectors using WBAN technology have been outlined. 2. WBAN Architecture WBAN is designed with special purpose sensor which can autonomously 
connect with various sensors and appliances, located inside and outside of a human body. Figure 1 demonstrates a simple WBAN architecture where the architecture is divided into several sections. Here we have classified the network architecture into four sections. The first section is the WBAN part which consists of several numbers of sensor nodes. These nodes are cheap and low-power nodes with inertial and physiological sensors, strategically placed on the human body. All the sensors can be used for continuous monitoring of movement, vital parameters like heart rate, ECG, Blood pressure etc. and the surrounding environment. There are vast monitoring systems are being used already based on wired connections. Any wired connection in a monitoring system can be problematic and awkward worn by a person and could restrict his mobility. So, WBAN can be a very effective solution in this area especially in a healthcare system where a patient needs to be monitored continuously and requires mobility. The next section is 
the coordination node where the entire sensor nodes will directly connected with a coordination node known as Central Control Unit (CCU). CCU takes the responsibility to collect information from the sensor nodes and to deliver to the next section. For monitoring human body activities Figure 1. WBAN Architecture. Md. _PERSON_ et al. 55 there is no such wireless technology is fixed for targeting WBAN. Most popular wireless technologies used for medical monitoring system are WLAN, WiFi, GSM, 3G, 4G,WPAN (Bluetooth, ZigBee) etc. [1]. Except Cellular network standard all of these technologies are commonly available for short distance communication. WMTS (Wireless Medical Telemetry Service) and Ultra-Wide Band [1] are another technology that could be used for body monitoring system"

175994828,"She's following God's will, or God's command not to touch the tree in the middle of the Garden. But in some ways, _NAME_ is the Garden, and Eve is the Nile or the river that runs through the Garden. There is a double meaning in that story, but put both meaning together, and the rest is clearer. Its not untrue, but it comes back to the question of authority. The lovers are following the authority blindly, out of faith and love. They don't know really good and evil until they try evil, and then it is the Devil's card. Its not morality, it is faith, which is pre-moral in a sense. They don't know first hand the bad, only the good, if they accept it. But they are given the choice, and they choose the Man instead of the God. So it is an analogy to humanism. The Devil is the perfect humanist, who ""frees"" the individual, or tempts them to do so. What the Church called it was grace, not morality. So before the bad decision, they are in a state of grace, and when they decide to make their own determination 
of good and evil, they fall from grace, and then they are not in tune with nature and their environment, they become alienated from it, and from each others as well, yet bound to them at the same time. That's kind of a secular humanist interpretation. Not particularly useful. What happens here I assume, is the sacrament of ordination. So you have the high priest, which you can see as the Pope, bestowing that power to others, so they become like him. The power of the key is to bind things and unbind things. So what is bound on Earth, is also bound in Heavens and vice versa. Its the power to reconcile from an alienated world. Its also the definition of religion, so the power of the key is the power of religion, this time seen as an institution, because the power of the keys are given to certain people, the authorities. They in turn, can apply that power for other sacraments, two of them being baptism, that take out the temptation to rebel in the story above, or marriage, that makes the same act above acceptable 
and good. But overall, it is the power of giving mercy and forgiveness, which is a divine power, so it has to be given from above. So it deals more about giving back a state of grace than about good and evil directly. If anything, it is going away from it and getting back in line with what should be, which is beyond good and evil. Its about redemption from it."

I’m going through my own shit as well and I am on an emotional roller coaster ride that feels like it ends in a black tunnel with no more rails. I can tell you that reaching out to people and getting support is a great first step acknowledgement that you want to feel and be better. No one wants to feel and be in pain forever. Right now I feel good so my thoughts are actually kind of clear for once. I have a 5 year old that means everything to me. I can’t imagine how you feel but I can tell you that your life is “your life” and their life is “their life”. We can’t control how other people feel or think but we can control ourself. You can make the choice to be happy and instead of persuading your daughter that the life she has is wrong. You can show her that you can be happy by being a loving and caring person and to respect yourself. Maybe 
if she sees that you are happy or at least making strides to be happy, she will feed off positivity and then show her that respecting your body and loving yourself should always come first. This is how you can truly be happy with others. PM me if you ever want to chat more. Like I said I’m going through my own stuff too but I always feel better when people write me and I chat with them. Good luck and I really hope you find happiness within yourself so it influences others in the process."

175994838,"It may take a few weeks for you to notice a difference but the symptoms could begin to decrease within your first week. I am currently on 100mg/daily. I was on a much lower dose in the beginning. Over time as new issues have arrived we have agreed on higher doses. I have been on Zoloft since 2016. I tried 4 other medications before I discovered Zoloft. I am very happy with it, just be patient. Give it time to work, if you don't feel better within a month talk to your doctor about an increase. I do want to warn you against running out of medicine, forgetting to take it, or stopping suddenly. I forgot my bottle at home when I went out of town, after 3 days I felt the depression more than ever, but I am on a high dosage and have been for years now, just be mindful and remember to take the medicine so it can do it's job."
